D.  A person shall not ignite fireworks within a motor vehicle or throw fireworks from a motor vehicle, nor shall a person place or throw ignited fireworks into or at a motor vehicle or at or near a person or group of people. 
E.  Private individuals shall be subject to the penalties in section 8.04.120 for violation of this chapter. 
F.  All persons using fireworks of any kind shall be liable for any personal injury or any loss of property resulting from the use of fireworks. 
G.  Fireworks shall not be sold in any area other than that which is zoned C-1. Fireworks shall only be sold between June 20 and July 6 of each year. Additionally, three (3) days prior to including New Year's Day, Chinese New Year, Cinco de Mayo of each year, and the sixteenth of September. Hours of sale shall be between 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. each and every day of legal sale, with the exceptions of July 3, July 4, and December 31 during which sales may be made between the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. 
H.  Fireworks can only be discharged: 
1.  Until 10:00 p.m. from June 20 to July 2, and can only be discharged until 12:00 midnight on July 3 and July 4; 
2.  Until 10:00 p.m. three (3) days preceding and including Chinese New Year; 
3.  Until 10:00 p.m. three (3) days preceding and including Cinco de Mayo; 
4.  Until 10:00 p.m. three (3) days preceding and including the sixteenth of September; 
5.  Until 10:00 p.m. three (3) days preceding New Year's Day, and can only be discharged until 1:00 a.m. on New Year's Day. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 1, 5-18-2015) 
8.04.070 - Inspection. 
    The city of Belen fire chief or any certified law enforcement officer may, at any reasonable hour, enter and inspect the premises, building or any structure temporary or permanently located at the site designated for the sale, packaging or handling of permitted devices. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 7, 5-18-2015) 
8.04.080 - Seizure of fireworks and revocation of permits. 
A.  The city of Belen fire chief or designee shall inspect the fireworks stands for conformance to this chapter. 
B.  The city of Belen fire chief or designee shall seize, take, remove or cause to be removed at the expense of the permit holder, all stocks of fireworks offered or exposed for sale, stored or held in violation of this chapter. 
C.  Any vendor convicted of violating this chapter will not be issued a new city permit for a period of two (2) years from the date of revocation of the previous city permit. 
D.  The New Mexico State Fire Marshal's Office will be informed of any vendor violating this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 8, 5-18-2015) 
8.04.090 - Prohibited devices. 
A.  It is illegal to sell, possess or discharge any and all bottle rockets, moon rockets, and whistling moon travelers within the municipal limits of the city of Belen, in addition to all other rockets containing one (1) ounce or less of chemical composition. 
B.  No firework shall after discharge lift more than ten (10) feet in air or six (6) feet in diameter. 
C.  The following are prohibited fireworks within the city of Belen: 
1.  Aerial devices; 
2.  Stick-type rockets; 
3.  Ground audible devices; 
4.  Any firework or device with a "warning" label; 
5.  Any firework that: 
a.  Is flammable with report; 
b.  Shoots flaming balls; 
c.  Shoots flaming balls with report. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 9, 5-18-2015) 
8.04.100 - Permissible fireworks. 
A.  Permissible fireworks are: 
1.  Ground and hand-held sparkling and smoke devices; 
2.  Cone fountains; 
3.  Crackling devices; 
4.  Cylindrical fountains; 
5.  Flitter sparklers; 
6.  Illuminating torches; 
7.  Toy smoke devices; 
8.  Wheels. 
B.  Any firework with a "caution" label. 
C.  Any firework that: 
1.  Emits showers of sparks; 
2.  Spins on ground, emits flame and sparks; 
3.  Moves on ground, emits showers of sparks; 
4.  Emits crackling sparks. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 10, 5-18-2015) 
8.04.110 - Theatrical pyrotechnics articles. 
A.  All places where theatrical pyrotechnics articles are manufactured, stored, sold or displayed shall be in compliance with the code of safety standards published by the National Fire Protection Association for the use of pyrotechnics before a proximate audience. 
B.  A special pyrotechnics permit shall be obtained by the office of the fire chief at least thirty (30) days prior. A permit fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) is to be paid for a theatrical pyrotechnics permit. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 11, 5-18-2015) 
8.04.120 - Criminal violations. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any provisions of this chapter shall be found guilty of a misdemeanor and be fined not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or imprisoned for a period of not more than ninety (90) days, or both fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 2015-06, § 12, 5-18-2015) 
Chapter 8.08 - GARBAGE, TRASH AND WASTE SERVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-14, §§ 1, 2(Att.), adopted Nov. 6, 2017, repealed Ch. 8.08 in its entirety and enacted a new Ch. 8.08 to read as set out herein. Former Ch. 3.24, §§ 8.08.010-8.08.200, pertained to garbage, trash and refuse and derived from Ord. No. 2012-02, adopted Feb. 20, 2012. 

8.08.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    "Ashes" means the remains from fires. 
    "Business, commercial establishment or institution" means any structure or premises not defined as a residence. 
    "Code enforcement officer" is a city official charged with enforcement of this chapter and other provisions of this code relating to public health. Notwithstanding any authorization of the code enforcement officer by this chapter, all decisions shall be subject to the review by the city manager. 
    "Commercial garbage or trash" means wastes produced by a business, commercial establishment or institution. 
    "Construction and demolition debris" means materials generally considered to be not water soluble and nonhazardous in nature, including, but not limited to, steel, glass, brick, concrete, asphalt roofing materials, pipe, gypsum wallboard and lumber from the construction or destruction of a structure, and includes rocks, soil, tree remains, trees and other vegetative matter that normally results from land clearing. 
    "Contractor" is the private refuse collection contractor to whom the city has awarded a contract for the collection and hauling of the city residential and commercial solid waste. 
    "Garbage" means wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food and wastes from the growing, handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    "Hauler" is any person, joint enterprise or corporation who collects garbage, trash or refuse from any property not owned by the person, joint enterprise or corporation. 
    "Industrial garbage or trash" means wastes produced by an industrial or manufacturing operation. 
    "Litter" is garbage or trash found in public areas that has been intentionally or negligently discarded by any person. 
    "Manager" means the manager of the city of Belen or his/her authorized representative. 
    Residential garbage or trash" means wastes produced by a family dwelling unit. 
    "Rubbish" means any material that is considered unimportant or valueless. 
    "Single- or multifamily dwelling units" means apartments, roominghouses and boardinghouses, but shall not include hotels, tourist courts, motels, motor courts, trailer courts or apartment hotels. 
    "Trash" means any discarded matter, including combustible trash, such as paper, plastic, and wood; noncombustible trash, such as metal, dirt, rock, concrete, asphalt, glass, crockery, and other mineral waste: street rubbish, such as street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catch-basin dirt and contents of litter receptacles. Trash shall not include wastes from commercial operations, nor shall it include wastes resulting from industrial and manufacturing operations. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.020 - Accumulation of garbage, trash and debris-Removal. 
A.  No person shall permit to accumulate upon premises owned, leased or occupied by him/her any garbage or trash, except in covered watertight containers made of metal or plastic. 
B.  No person shall throw, place, sweep, dump, dispose or accumulate any litter, garbage or trash on any property. 
C.  No person shall cause or permit to remain upon any property, any dead animal or hazardous material to public health. 
D.  Any unauthorized accumulation of garbage or trash, or rubbish, is declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. 
E.  Subject to any limitations otherwise provided by law, the code enforcement officer is authorized to inspect any private property where there is reasonable cause to suspect that violations may exist. 
1.  If, on the basis of such inspections, the code enforcement officer finds that any of subsections A. through D. have not been complied with or that a health hazard exists, the code enforcement officer shall notify the owner of the premises to properly correct such conditions, within a designated period of time not to exceed ten (10) days. 
2.  Upon failure of corrective action, within the time prescribed the city manager may contract for the correction of the violation, or order its correction by the city, at the expense of the property owner. 
3.  The cost of correction shall become a lien on the property, unless paid for by the property owner. The lien shall be enforced and foreclosed according to applicable state law. 
F.  Costs for correction using city resources the violation shall be determined on the basis of labor and equipment at a normal rental rate per day, plus any direct costs paid by the city. 
G.  Nothing in subsection E. of this section shall be construed to require any notice before the filing of a court action for a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.030 - Garbage and trash-Pre-collection practices. 
A.  Garbage and trash shall be placed and maintained in collection containers as defined by the city and/or city contractor. 
B.  It shall be the responsibility of all persons to dismantle and/or flatten all boxes or crates, regardless of construction, and to bundle all tree clippings, before placing in collection containers. 
C.  Any hazardous or construction material shall not be placed in collection containers, and the producers of such materials will be required to individually contract with an independent contractor or hauler for the disposal of such waste: 
D.  All garbage or trash shall be secured into a plastic bag(s) prior to disposal in the provided container. 
E.  Motor oil and similar liquid materials shall be disposed in accordance with Environmental Protection Agency and New Mexico Environment Department standards. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.040 - Garbage and trash service mandatory. 
A.  All utility account holders within the municipal boundaries shall have trash service as defined by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.050 - Garbage and trash containers. 
A.  Garbage and trash containers shall be provided by the contractor or hauler and shall be made of metal or plastic, with tight-fitting covers, and shall be watertight. 
B.  All garbage and trash containers provided by the contractor or hauler shall be kept in a neat and sanitary condition at all times. 
C.  Residential Containers. The contractor or hauler shall provide one (1) standard ninety-five (95) gallon cart to each residential unit, these carts may only be loaded to a maximum of one-hundred and fifty (150) pounds prior to pick up. 
D.  Commercial Containers. All commercial containers shall be provided through the contractor or hauler (available in ninety-five (95) gallon; two (2) cubic yard; three (3) cubic yard; four (4) cubic yard; six (6) cubic yard and eight (8) cubic yard containers) for all types of solid waste except for materials of toxic or highly-explosive nature. Compactors may also be available to the business, but must be coordinated with the contractor in order to obtain this type of service. 
E.  All residential and commercial users shall comply with the rules and regulations established by the city for the use, care and location of containers. 
F.  All containers shall be placed where directed by the contractor or hauler unless otherwise specified by the code enforcement officer. It is unlawful to block or impede access to a container that is located as directed. 
G.  Containers serving residential accounts shall be used only by residential customers for garbage and trash generated on residential premises; those serving commercial accounts shall be used only by the customer served by the particular account and those authorized by that customer. Dumping in violation of this provision is considered a misdemeanor and will be punished accordingly to the extent of the law. 
H.  All commercial establishments shall retain the appropriate number of container(s) in order to accommodate the volume of waste generated. All commercial establishments are advised to work with the recommendations of the contractor to ensure cost and pick-up schedule efficiency as defined by the contractor and the city. If a dispute occurs and the customer cannot agree with the method(s) advised by the contractor, the city manager shall have the final authority in the matter and shall render a final decision in which the contractor and commercial establishment shall adhere to. 
I.  Any restaurant or other business that deals with grease or oil shall retain the proper container for proper disposal. 
J.  No person shall remove someone else's receptacle for their own use. Such removal shall be prosecuted as theft to the fullest extent of the law. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.060 - Garbage or trash hauling. 
    Any garbage or trash transported by a vehicle through the city of Belen shall be covered as to prevent litter. Any litter that has fallen from a moving vehicle is the responsibility of the driver and/or contractor. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.070 - Collection occurrences. 
A.  The collection of garbage and trash in residential areas shall occur at least once per week. 
B.  Residents are responsible for ensuring the container is placed in the proper location prior to pick up as defined by the city or contractor. 
C.  Residents shall return the containers back to their property within 12 hours after collection has occurred. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.080 - Toxic, flammable or explosive waste. 
    Toxic, highly flammable or explosive materials shall not be placed in containers for regular collection, but shall be disposed of in accordance with any applicable state and federal regulations, at the expense of the person accumulating the same. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.090 - Lost or damage to containers. 
A.  It is unlawful to maliciously damage or modify any container owned by the contractor or any hauler. 
B.  Any person who damages any container provided for the residential or commercial users shall be liable to the contractor or hauler for the cost of repair or replacement of such container. 
C.  It is prohibited for any person, to be on or in any garbage or trash container. 
D.  Account holders shall be responsible for lost or stolen containers. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.100 - Construction sites and transportation of materials. 
    All person(s) shall secure a disposal container from a licensed trash hauler for any permitted construction site within the municipal boundaries, and shall maintain the integrity of such container until project completion. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.110 - Scavenging prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person or animal to remove garbage or trash from any container without property owner's prior authorization. It shall be the responsibility of the animal's owner to control the actions of their animal. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.120 - Regulations adopted. 
    The laws and regulations promulgated and published by the New Mexico Environment Department, along with subsequent revisions and amendments are adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.130 - Reserved. 
8.08.140 - Medical waste. 
    No person shall deposit any medical waste including hypodermic needles or syringes in any container that is not approved for this purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.150 - Exclusive rights. 
A.  The city shall enforce a general system for the collection and disposal of garbage and trash within the city. The city shall have the exclusive right to collect and dispose of garbage and trash within the city or shall have the right to grant to a contractor, the sole and exclusive contract and privilege to provide refuse collection, disposal and removal services within the territorial jurisdiction of the city. 
B.  Nothing in this chapter prohibits residents from receiving recycling services-when the city or the city's contractor is not offering the same. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.160 - Garbage collection rates. 
    The rates for collection of waste are as follows: 
A.  Residences. The account holder shall be charged at the current adopted rate per month for one (1) cart for one (1) pickup a week. The account holder shall also be charged at the current adopted rate for over filling/over-loading the cart. Additional carts may be provided at the current adopted rate per month (maximum of two (2) total carts). 
    The account holder shall be responsible for special pickups at the current adopted rate. 
    On July 1 of every year, the fees shall be adjusted automatically to reflect a three (3) percent increase. 
B.  Basic Commercial. The account holder shall be charged at the current adopted rate per month for one (1) cart for one (1) pickup per week. Additional carts may be provided for a fee at the current adopted rate per month (maximum of two (2) total carts). 
    The account holder shall be responsible for special pickups at the current adopted rate. 
    On July 1 of every year, the fees shall be adjusted automatically to reflect a three (3) percent increase. 
C.  Business establishments with dumpsters shall be assessed a fee at the current adopted rate. 
D.  Extra on-call rates for commercial containers shall be charged at the current adopted rate. 
E.  Front-end loader compactor monthly base rates shall be charged at the current adopted rate. 
F.  If an occupant of a property does not have water or sewer utilities provided by the city, the occupant shall be charged a deposit for a container at the currently adopted rate and fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.170 - Special rates. 
A.  Special Pickup Services. A special fee shall be charged by the city or contractor for all special pickup services at an assessed rate according to the type of load and the requirements of resources needed to complete this task. The items to be disposed shall be placed curbside. 
B.  Convenience Center Fee and Permit. The city's convenience center shall be made available for Belen residents to dispose of excess trash or garbage by purchase of permits at a rate established by the city and/or its approved contractor. 
    By approval of a resolution, the governing body may offer use of the city's convenience center to residents outside of the city limits; however, if the city allows the contractor to take over the duties of this convenience center, the city and contractor shall then establish fees for using this center, and shall have the authority to allow or deny any users as it deems appropriate. 
1.  Permits shall be purchased at Belen City Hall or from the city contractor. 
2.  All persons who purchase a permit must provide a proof of residency. 
3.  Any operated convenience center shall not accept any form of payment. 
4.  No permit shall be reproduced. Violations of this section shall be prosecuted as fraud and theft to the fullest extent of the law. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.180 - Fee included in utility bill. 
    The garbage and trash fee for residential, multi-residential and commercial account holders shall be included in the monthly utility bill and shall be subject to all provisions set forth in section 13.12.100. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.190 - Applicability of provisions. 
    This chapter shall be applicable to all land areas within the municipality boundaries. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
8.08.200 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Violation of the provisions of this chapter or failure to comply with any of its requirements shall constitute a misdemeanor. Any person who violates this chapter or fails to comply with any of its terms shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 2017-14, § 2(Att.), 11-6-2017) 
Chapter 8.12 - NUISANCES 
Sections: 

8.12.010 - Foul odors. 
    That if any person shall suffer or permit any cellar, vault, private drain, pool, privy, sewer or ground or building upon any premises within the corporate limits of the city of Belen owned, used or occupied by him or her, or of which he or she shall be agent, having charge of same, to become foul, offensive, nauseous, dangerous or injurious to the public health, or suffer or permit any such ground, building or premises to become foul, offensive, nauseous or dangerous to the neighborhood or travelers by reason of stagnant water, dead animals or from any other cause or causes, he or she shall be punished as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 10 § 1919) 
8.12.020 - Dead animals. 
    If any person shall suffer any animal belonging to him or her, or in his or her charge, which may die of disease or otherwise, to be in or upon any street, alley or other grounds, or place within the city, public or private, for a space of twenty-four (24) hours after the same shall have died, he or she shall be punished as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 10 § 2, 1919) 
8.12.030 - Foul liquids or substances. 
    If any person shall allow to flow from any house, shop, factory, stable, slaughter house or place, any foul or nauseous liquids or substance of any kind whatever, into or upon any adjacent ground or lot or into any street, alley or ditch within the city, so as to be offensive, nauseous, hurtful or dangerous; and any person who shall deposit in any such place any filth, litter or refuse of any carcass so as to be offensive, nauseous, hurtful or dangerous to any portion of the inhabitants of said city, he or she shall be punished as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 10 § 3, 1919) 
8.12.040 - Littering. 
A.  It is unlawful to throw, place, dump or bury any cans, bottles, papers, trash, debris, rubbish, weeds, brush, branches or offensive matter in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place in the city of Belen. 
B.  It is unlawful to place any cans, bottles, papers, trash, debris, rubbish, weeds, brush, branches or offensive matter in the bed of any vehicle or upon a vehicle's trailer that is not bagged or otherwise fully covered and contained. 
C.  Any person, business, firm or corporation violating of this section upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. 295 §§ 1, 2, 1958: Ord. 10 § 4, 1919) 
(Ord. No. 2015-05, 4-20-2015) 
8.12.050 - Animals. 
    Housing, penting up, corralling, or grazing of horses, cows, pigs, chickens, pigeons or any other animal and fowl which may be offensive to any person is declared to be a nuisance under this chapter. Further, none of the above animals or fowl under any circumstances may be kept within a radius of two hundred fifty (250) feet from any residence within the city limits of Belen. Any violators hereof shall be punished as provided for in this chapter. 
(Ord. 10, 1960: Ord. 10 § 5, 1919) 
8.12.060 - Tainted meat. 
    If any person shall expose for sale, in any market, house, shop or elsewhere in the city of Belen, any tainted or putrid meat or provisions which from these or other causes may be deemed unwholesome, every such person shall be punished as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 10 § 6, 1919) 
8.12.070 - Water storage in open dirt or earth tanks prohibited. 
A.  Storing water in open dirt or earth tanks for any purpose within the city limits is prohibited. This order due to unsanitary conditions and breeding of flies and mosquitoes. 
B.  Any person offending against the foregoing provisions of this section shall be punished for each offense by a fine of not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and the costs of the prosecution, and in default of payment thereof be imprisoned in the city or county jail for a period of not more than twenty (20) days. 
(Ord. 308 §§ 1, 2, 1960) 
8.12.080 - Removal of rubbish, etc. 
A.  Definitions. For the purpose of this section the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations for and names given herein: 
    "Garbage" means putrescible, animal, and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    "Person" means person, individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company, association, or any other entity owning or utilizing as tenant, landlord, or otherwise any real property in the city of Belen. 
    "Refuse" means and includes, but is not limited to garbage, ashes, and petroleum products. 
    "Rubbish" means and includes, but is not limited to barrels, bedding, cans, cardboard, car bodies, drums, crockery, glass, grass cuttings, leaves, metal, paper, rags, rubber, sawdust, trees, tree stumps, weeds, wire, wood scraps, and similar materials. 
B.  No person shall permit the accumulation of debris, refuse, rubbish, or garbage, trash or other similar material to accumulate on any portion of their property when said accumulation constitutes a detriment to the public health and a fire hazard to the community. 
C.  In the event said accumulation is allowed to exist by any person or any property within the city limits of the city of Belen for a period of five days after being notified by a duly authorized agent of the city council to remove same, the city may: 
1.  Remove all of said refuse, rubbish, garbage, or similar material and all expenses incurred by the city in said removal are hereby deemed to constitute a lien on the said real property and collectible by the city as per pertinent provisions of lien statutes of the state of New Mexico. 
2.  Provide owner or occupant with a twenty-four (24) hour notice to forthwith remove same, failure of which shall constitute violation of the section with penalties as hereinafter provided. 
D.  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and/or imprisonment in the city jail for not more than fifteen (15) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 1990-3 §§ 1-4) 
8.12.090 - Weeds. 
A.  In case there shall be weeds located upon any lot within the city of Belen, the city shall have the power to notify the owner of such lot to cut or cause to be removed all of said weeds within forty-eight (48) hours. In case of failure or refusal on the part of the owner to so do or cause to be removed all of such weeds within the time prescribed, the city may cut or remove said weeds and shall send a bill for the reasonable cost of so cutting or removing the same, which bill shall be computed in accordance with the following schedule: 
Cost of Equipment and Operator Fees 
Bulldozer $100.00 per hour Grader 100.00 per hour Backhoe 100.00 per hour Dump track 100.00 per hour Weed cutter 100.00 per hour  
    If an extra laborer is needed, additional charge will be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per hour, per additional laborer. 
    The minimum charge shall be for one hour. 
    In case of failure or refusal on the part of the owner to pay such cost, an assessment may be made by the city of Belen and a lien placed upon such premises of the owner for the cost of the cutting and/or removal of the weeds. 
B.  In the event that an owner of property located within the city of Belen desires that the city of Belen clean such private property for the owner on a voluntary basis, then such owner may hire the city of Belen for such services and shall compensate the city according to the rate schedule set forth above. In the event that such property owner fails or refuses to pay the city in accordance with the rate schedule set forth above, then the city shall exercise the same lien remedies outlined in subsection A of this section. 
(Ord. 1993-8 §§ 1, 2) 
8.12.100 - Reporting and removal of nuisances. 
    It is the duty of the marshal to ascertain and report to the city mayor the existence of any and all nuisances declared to be such by the foregoing sections, and whenever it shall appear that such nuisances exist, the mayor may direct the same to be abated and removed by such officers or persons as may be designated, and if such nuisance be found on private property, the said officer or person shall order the owner, agent or occupant thereof to remove and abate the same at his own expense within a reasonable time; and if such owner, agent or occupant shall fail, refuse or neglect to comply with the requirements of any such order, the said officer or person by order of the mayor may cause such nuisance to be removed, and all expenses incurred thereby shall be paid by such owner, agent or occupant, or such other person as shall have caused or permitted the same, and such expense may be recovered from such owner, agent or occupant, or from such other person as shall have caused or permitted the same, by action brought before the justice of the peace in the name of the city. 
(Ord. 10 § 8, 1919) 
8.12.110 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person offending against the foregoing provisions of this chapter shall be punished for each offense by a fine of not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and the costs of the prosecution, and in default of payment thereof be imprisoned in the city or county jail for a period of not more than twenty (20) days. 
(Ord. 10 § 7, 1919) 
Chapter 8.14 - UNLAWFUL SOLICITATION OR PANHANDLING 

8.14.010 - Purpose. 
    The city council finds that panhandling in an aggressive manner and certain forms of solicitation as identified herein are extremely disturbing and disruptive to the public and contribute to a loss of access to and enjoyment of public place, and to an enhanced sense of fear, intimidation, and disorder. Such activities negatively impact significant governmental interests, including: 
A.  Protection of citizens from physical threats or injury and from damage to property; 
B.  Prevention of harassment and intimidation of members of the public; 
C.  Prevention of violent crime; 
D.  Traffic control and public safety; 
E.  Orderly movement of traffic and pedestrians; and 
F.  Provision and maintenance of a safe environment in areas designed to attract revenue. 
    This chapter is intended to promote these governmental interests and combat the negative effects of panhandling in an aggressive manner and certain forms of solicitation. It is not intended to limit any persons from exercising their Constitutional right to solicit funds, picket, protest or engage in other Constitutionally protected activity. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2, 11-16-2015) 
8.14.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this section, terms shall be defined as follows: 
A.  "Aggressive manner" shall mean any of the following: 
1.  Approaching or speaking to a person, or following a person before, during or after soliciting, if that conduct is intended or is likely to cause a reasonable person to fear bodily harm to oneself or to another or damage to or loss of property or otherwise be intimidated into giving money or other thing of value; 
2.  Continuing to solicit from a person or continuing to engage that person after the person has given a negative response to such soliciting; 
3.  Intentionally or recklessly touching or causing physical contact with another person or that person's property without that person's consent in the course of soliciting; 
4.  Intentionally or recklessly blocking or interfering with the safe or free passage of a pedestrian or vehicle by any means, including unreasonably causing a pedestrian or vehicle operator to take evasive action to avoid physical contact; 
5.  Using violent, obscene or threatening gestures toward a person solicited; 
6.  Following behind, ahead or alongside the person being solicited, with the intent of asking that person for money or other things of value, after the person being solicited has walked away from or verbally declined the panhandler; 
7.  Soliciting from a person in a vehicle after the person has declined the panhandler by any reasonable means, including, but not limited to, closing a window, honking, or the like; 
8.  Speaking in a volume unreasonably loud under the circumstances; or 
9.  Using a minor to solicit on behalf of an adult, whether by passive, active or verbal actions of the minor, including, but not limited to, directing, influencing, or allowing a minor to approach any vehicle. Provided, that this prohibition shall not apply to an organized fund-raising activity for an organization such as a school, club or service organization and in which an adult is present and supervising the minor(s). 
B.  "Aggressive panhandling" shall mean any panhandling in an aggressive manner as defined herein. 
C.  "Automated teller machine" shall mean a device, linked to a financial institution's account records, which is able to carry out transactions, including, but not limited to: account transfers, deposits, cash withdrawals, balance inquiries and mortgage and loan payments. 
D.  "Automated teller machine facility" shall mean the area comprised of one (1) or more automated teller machines and any adjacent space. 
E.  "Check cashing business" shall mean any person duly licensed by the superintendent of banks to engage in the business of cashing checks, drafts or money orders. 
F.  "Financial institution" shall mean any banking corporation, credit union, foreign exchange office or like institution. 
G.  "Minor" shall mean a person who is seventeen (17) years old or younger. 
H.  "Public place" shall mean a place owned or occupied by a governmental entity or to which the public or a substantial group of persons has access, including, but not limited to, any street, highway, parking lot or sidewalk; plaza; transportation structure, facility or vehicle; school; place of amusement, park or playground; or the doorways, entrances, lobbies, hallways, aisles and common areas, both interior and exterior, of commercial establishments to which the public is generally invited. 
I.  "Panhandling" shall mean any solicitation, begging or other means of requesting monetary donations made in person upon another person in any public place. Panhandling includes, but is not limited to, seeking donations by vocal appeal or by sitting or standing with a sign or other nonauditory indication that a donation is being sought. Panhandling does not include street performances, sales of products or items of value; or door-to-door solicitations, unless the property owner or occupant has posted notice or otherwise informed the panhandler that solicitations are not welcome. 
J.  "Soliciting" shall mean asking for money or objects of value, and shall include panhandling. 
K.  "Street performance" shall mean a performance of common art forms such as music, drama, literature and the like. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2, 11-16-2015) 
8.14.030 - Prohibited acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person to engage in soliciting as follows: 
A.  In an aggressive manner in any public place; 
B.  Reserved. 
C.  Within fifteen (15) feet of public toilets; 
D.  Within fifteen (15) feet of any entrance or exit of any financial institution, check cashing business or automated teller machine facility without the consent of the owner of the property or another person legally in possession of such facilities; 
E.  While under the influence of alcohol or a controlled substance; 
F.  By stating that funds are needed to meet a specific need, when the solicitor has the funds to meet that need, does not intend to use funds to meet that need or does not have that need; 
G.  In any public transportation vehicle; 
H.  Within fifteen (15) feet of any handicapped parking space; or 
I.  In an area unless the area is sufficiently illuminated to allow the person being solicited to fully observe the solicitor at a distance of fifteen (15) feet. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2, 11-16-2015) 
8.14.040 - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be found guilty of a misdemeanor and be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for a period of not more than ninety (90) days, or both fined and imprisoned. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2, 11-16-2015) 
8.14.050 - Severance. 
    If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this law is held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, it shall in no way affect the validity of any remaining portions of this law. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2, 11-16-2015) 
Chapter 8.16 - WHOLESALE PRODUCE DEALERS 
Sections: 

8.16.010 - Generally. 
    From and after the passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter all wholesale produce dealers handling, selling and distributing fresh fruits and vegetables within the city of Belen shall be under the supervision of the city of Belen. This measure is conducive to the promotion of the health and general welfare of the city of Belen (14-3807-3808: 1947). 
(Ord. 264 § 1, 1949) 
8.16.020 - Definitions. 
    In this chapter certain words and terms shall be defined as follows: 
    "Farmer" and "producer" are synonymous and mean a person who is actually engaged in the business of growing and producing fruits and vegetables on land in New Mexico owned or leased by himself or herself or which he or she works on shares. 
    "Peddler" means every person, firm, association, partnership or corporation engaged in the business of selling, bartering, exchanging or offering to sell, exchange or barter any fruits or vegetables in wholesale or retail quantities to another person, wholesaler, retailer, jobber, broker, clubs, restaurant institutions directly or indirectly from a truck, trailer or any mode of transportation on which said merchandise is a cargo or part of a cargo. 
    "Retailer" means any grocery, market, hospital, hotel, club, restaurant or other institution, or any person who handles fresh fruits and vegetables for retail sale to the public in their natural state or in the form of meals. 
    "Solicitor" means every person, firm, association, partnership or corporation engaged in the business of selling, bartering, exchanging or offering to sell, exchange or barter any fresh fruits or vegetables in wholesale or retail quantities to a wholesaler, retailer, jobber, broker, clubs, restaurants, and other institutions who has a salesperson or salespeople in their employment or work as agents or are associated with said business to take orders from above mentioned businesses and to deliver such fruits and vegetables at the same date or a later date. 
    "Wholesale produce dealer" means every person, firm, association, partnership or corporation engaged in the business of selling, bartering, exchanging or offering to sell, exchange or barter, any fresh fruits or vegetables in wholesale quantities, or to another wholesaler, jobber, broker, retailer, hospital, hotel, club, restaurant, or to other institutions, or to any person who intends to resell, or is not the ultimate consumer of the same. 
(Ord. 264 § 2, 1949) 
8.16.030 - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm, association or corporation, to do business as a wholesale produce dealer, farmer, peddler and solicitor within the city of Belen without first having obtained a license as would be required in each specific case, as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 264 § 3, 1949) 
8.16.040 - License-Building requirements. 
    No license shall be granted hereunder to any wholesale produce dealer who does not occupy and do business as owner or tenant in a regularly established building, store or warehouse, for the purpose of wholesale merchandising in fresh fruits and vegetables. Said building must contain the following: 
A.  Adequate refrigeration and storage facilities shall be maintained at a temperature of forty (40) degrees Fahrenheit or lower. The walls thereof shall be constructed of concrete or cleanly painted wood or equivalent construction and shall have proper insulation. The floors shall be of concrete or equivalent with proper floor drain. Water hydrants installed so that water is available for cleanliness. 
B.  The entire premises shall be kept free of flies and other insects and supplies with adequately covered refuse facilities for spoiled fruits and vegetables. 
C.  Adequate toilet facilities shall be maintained on the premises for employees thereof. 
(Ord. 264 § 4, 1949) 
8.16.050 - License-Building inspection. 
    Before any license is granted hereunder to any wholesale produce dealer, his or her place of business shall be inspected by an authorized officer or inspector of the city of Belen and certified by having adequate refrigeration and storage and sanitary facilities for the sanitary and safe wholesale merchandising of fresh fruits and vegetables. 
(Ord. 264 § 5, 1949) 
8.16.060 - License-Application. 
    Any wholesale produce dealer desiring to secure a license hereunder to operate his or her business shall apply to the city clerk for said license. The city clerk shall immediately notify their authorized officer or inspector of such application, and the officer or inspector shall forthwith make an inspection of the applicant's place of business as provided in Sections 8.16.040 and 8.16.050 of this chapter, and certify the result of such inspection as favorable or unfavorable to the city clerk. If the certificate of inspection is favorable to the applicant the city clerk shall forthwith issue a license under occupation tax laws. No such license shall be transferable unless a new inspection is made upon transferring of license. 
(Ord. 264 § 6, 1949) 
8.16.070 - Deliveries. 
    All fruits and vegetables handled by any wholesale produce dealer must be promptly removed by such dealer from the car, truck or other mode of transportation by which it is delivered to him or her, and placed in proper storage rooms of such wholesale produce dealer. 
(Ord. 264 § 7, 1949) 
8.16.080 - Inspections. 
A.  Any duly authorized inspector or officer of the city of Belen is empowered and authorized to inspect, during regular business hours, any fresh fruits and vegetables within the city limits as now existing and as hereinafter extended, which are in the possession of any wholesale produce dealer, retailer, farmer and peddler and solicitor for the purpose of sale to any citizen of or places of business of Belen. 
B.  Any duly authorized inspector or officer of the city of Belen is empowered to destroy or order the disposal of any and all fruits and vegetables which in his or her opinion or from such inspection are putrid, rotten, decayed, diseased, contaminated or of such inferior quality as to be dangerous to health or unfit for human consumption. 
(Ord. 264 § 8, 1949) 
8.16.090 - Purchasing produce from unlicensed dealers prohibited. 
    It is a violation of this chapter for a retailer, doing business in the city of Belen, to purchase fresh fruits or vegetables from any person, association, partnership, or corporation that does not have their license required by this chapter. 
(Ord. 264 § 9, 1949) 
8.16.100 - Farmer or producer permit. 
    Any farmer or producer may secure from the city clerk, free of charge, a years' permit to sell fruits and vegetables to retailers or wholesalers, upon filing an affidavit under oath with the city clerk, giving his or her name, the location of the premises which he or she owns or rents and upon which the fruit or vegetables are grown, and a statement that no fruit or vegetables will be sold to retailers or wholesalers except that which are grown or produced on said premises. 
    In the case of doubt the farmer or producer shall have to show a letter or certificate from his or her county agent certifying that said farmer or producer has raised such fruits or vegetables at that specific time of season that the product is in season. Any interested person shall have cause to demand proof of said farmer or producer to show said certificate or letter from his or her respective county agent. Such permit issued by the city clerk shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. 264 § 10, 1949) 
8.16.110 - Peddler license. 
    A peddler shall have to apply for a license from the city clerk. The city clerk shall then notify an authorized officer or inspector to inspect the merchandise that said peddler may have to sell, trade or exchange wholesale or retail. This inspection must be in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, that the merchandise is in sanitary and saleable quality. The city clerk shall demand a certificate of sanitation and health and in the event applicant has been issued a certificate of sanitation by the inspector which shall be duly presented to the clerk, and the payment of fee, the clerk shall issue a license. It is further provided that the fee for the annual license to operate a business under the provisions of this section shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day. No license issued under the provisions of this chapter is transferable. 
(Ord. 264 § 11, 1949) 
8.16.120 - Solicitor license. 
    A solicitor shall have to apply for a license from the city clerk. The city clerk shall demand a certificate of sanitation and health for the applicant's place of business and in the event applicant has been issued a certificate of sanitation it shall be duly presented to the clerk, and the payment of fee, the clerk shall issue a license. It is further provided that the fee for the annual license to operate a business under the provisions of this section shall be eighty dollars ($80.00) per annum. No license issued under the provisions of this chapter is transferable. 
(Ord. 264 § 12, 1949) 
8.16.130 - Enforcement. 
    The duly authorized officers of the city of Belen including the police department, health department and city clerk and others having the duty of enforcing the ordinances of the city of Belen, shall enforce the provisions of this chapter and shall allow no wholesale produce dealer, retailer, farmer or producer, peddlers and solicitors without full compliance of this chapter herewith. 
(Ord. 264 § 14, 1949) 
8.16.140 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any persons violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction be fined no less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each sale, offer for sale, and exhibition for the purpose of sale by wholesale dealer, retailer, farmer or producer, peddlers and solicitors without full compliance of this chapter shall be and constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 264 § 13, 1949) 
Chapter 8.20 - OPEN BURNING[4] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Ord. No. 2009-10, §§ 1-14, adopted 11-9-2009, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as Ch. 8.20, §§ 8.20.010-8.20.140, was at the discretion of the editor. See also the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List. 

8.20.010 - Purpose. 
    This chapter is intended to amend the current ordinance to promote the public health, safety and welfare and to safeguard the health, comfort and living conditions of the citizens of Belen, New Mexico due to the air pollution and fire hazards of open burning and outdoor burning. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 1, 2009) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.020 - Applicability. 
    This chapter applies to all outdoor burning and refuse burning within the city of Belen, New Mexico: 
1.  This chapter does not apply to grilling or cooking using charcoal, wood, propane or natural gas in cooking or grilling appliances. 
2.  This chapter does not apply to burning in a stove, furnace, fireplace or other heating device within a building used for human habitation unless the material being burned includes refuse as defined in Section 8.20.050 of this chapter. 
3.  This chapter does not apply to the use of propane, acetylene, natural gas, gasoline or kerosene, in a device intended for heating, construction or maintenance activities. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 2, 2009) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 2, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.030 - Severability. 
    Should any portion of this chapter be declared unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this chapter shall not be affected. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 3, 2009) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 3, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.040 - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    "Bonfire" means an outdoor fire utilized for ceremonial purposes. 
    "Campfire" means a small outdoor fire intended for recreation or cooking; not including a fire intended for disposal of weeds, waste wood, or refuse. 
    "Clean wood" means natural wood which has not been painted, varnished, or coated with a similar material and has not been pressure treated with preservatives and does not contain resins or glues as in plywood or other composite wood products. 
    "Fire chief" means the fire chief of the city of Belen, New Mexico. 
    "Open burning" means the burning of materials wherein products of combustion are emitted directly into the ambient air without passing through a stack or chimney from an enclosed chamber. 
    "Outdoor burning" means any open burning. 
    "Recreational fire" means an outdoor fire burning materials other than rubbish where fuel being burned is not contained in an incinerator, outdoor fireplace, barbecue grill or barbecue pit and has a total fuel area of three (3) feet or less in diameter, and two (2) feet or less in height for pleasure, religious, ceremonial, cooking, warmth or similar purposes. 
    "Refuse" means any waste material except clean wood. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 4) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 4, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.050 - General prohibition on open burning, outdoor burning and refuse burning. 
    Open burning and refuse burning are prohibited in the city of Belen, New Mexico unless the burning is specifically permitted by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 5) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 5, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.060 - Materials that may not be burned. 
    Unless specific written approval has been obtained by the Belen Fire Department, the following materials may not be burned in an open fire, incinerator, burn barrel, furnace, stove or any other outdoor incineration or heating device: 
1.  Rubbish or garbage including, but not limited to, food wastes, food wraps, packing material, animal carcasses or waste, paint or painted materials, furniture, composite shingles, construction or demolition debris, or other household or business wastes. 
2.  Waste oil or used oil filters or other oily wastes except oil used in a heating device. 
3.  Asphalt, asphalt shingles, tar or tar paper and products containing asphalt. 
4.  Treated or painted wood including, but not limited to, plywood, composite wood products or other wood products that are painted, varnished, or which has been treated with preservatives containing arsenic, chromium, pentachlorophenol, or creosote. 
5.  Natural wood products greater than one (1) inch in diameter, or longer than four (4) feet in length. 
6.  Any plastic material including, but not limited to, nylon, polyvinyl chloride, "PVC" pipe or tuning or connectors, ABS, polystyrene or urethane foam, and synthetic fabrics, plastic films, and plastic containers. 
7.  Insulated wire. 
8.  Railroad ties. 
9.  Batteries. 
10.  Motor vehicle bodies or interiors. 
11.  Pathogenic wastes. 
12.  Asbestos or asbestos containing material. 
13.  Rubber including tires and synthetic rubber-like products. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 6) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 6, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.070 - Open burning of leaves, brush, clean wood and other vegetative debris. 
    Open burning of leaves, weeds, brush, stumps, clean wood and other vegetative debris is allowed only in accordance with the following provisions: 
1.  All allowed open burning shall be conducted in a safe, nuisance free manner, when wind and weather conditions are such as to minimize adverse effects and not create a health hazard or visibility hazard on roadways, railroads or airfields. 
2.  Provisions established in Section 8.20.090 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 7) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 7, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.080 - Burn barrels. 
    No person shall use or maintain a burn barrel in the city of Belen, New Mexico. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 8) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 8, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.090 - Burning permits and restrictions. 
1.  An outdoor campfire does not require a burn permit provided that the fire complies with all other applicable provisions of this chapter. 
2.  No person shall start or maintain an open burning without a burn permit issued by the fire chief or designee of the Belen Fire Department. 
3.  Any person responsible for burning leaves, brush, clean wood or other vegetative debris under Section 8.20.070 of this chapter shall obtain a burn permit before starting the fire. 
4.  Burn permits will be issued from the Belen Fire Department, 116 South Sixth Street, Belen, New Mexico, during normal business hours. The Belen Fire Chief shall maintain a running log of all permits issued throughout any given period. 
5.  Burn permits will be valid for a period of thirty (30) consecutive days from the original date of issue. Any burn permit that expires must be re-issued for an extension. 
6.  All burning must take place no earlier than one (1) hour after sunrise, and shall be extinguished and cold no later than one (1) hour before sunset; burning outside of this time is subject to Section 8.20.140, of this chapter. 
7.  The emission of smoke shall not be allowed to pass onto or across a public road or land strip such that a hazard is created by impairment of visibility. 
8.  No open burning shall be undertaken during periods when either the fire chief or National Weather Service has issued a burning ban such as a "red flag warning", or "fire weather watch" applicable to the area. 
9.  When weather conditions warrant, the fire chief may declare a burning moratorium on all open burning and temporarily suspend previously issued burn permits for open burning. 
10.  Open burning shall be conducted only on the property on which the materials were generated and permitted for. 
11.  Outdoor campfires and small bonfires for cooking, ceremonies or recreation are allowed; provided that the fire is confined by a control device or structure such as a fire ring or fire pit. Bonfires are allowed only if approved by and in accordance with provisions established by the fire chief. 
12.  Open burning shall be constantly attended and supervised by a competent person of at least eighteen (18) years of age until the fire is extinguished and is cold. The person shall have readily available for use such fire extinguishing equipment as may be necessary for the total control of the fire. 
13.  No materials may be burned upon any street, curb, alley, gutter, sidewalk or public way. 
14.  Any infringement of the conditions of a burn permit shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. Any violation of this chapter or burn permit shall void the permit and may cause for a suspension of issuance of any future request. 
15.  The fire chief reserves the right to refuse to authorize a burn permit to any resident. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 9) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 9, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.100 - Liability. 
    A person utilizing or maintaining an outdoor fire shall be responsible for all fire suppression costs and any other liability resulting from damage caused by the fire. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 10) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 10, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.110 - Right of entry and inspection. 
    The fire chief or any authorized officer, agent, employee or representative of the city of Belen, New Mexico may inspect any property for the purposes of ascertaining compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 11) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 11, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.120 - Enforcement. 
    The fire chief or any authorized officer, are authorized to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 12) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 12, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.130 - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall take effect and be in force thirty (30) days after its enactment and recording with the city clerk as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 13) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 13, 2-3-2014) 
8.20.140 - Penalties. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any provisions of this chapter shall be found guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or imprisoned for a period of not more than ninety (90) days, or both fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10, § 14) 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 14, 2-3-2014) 
Chapter 8.22 - POINT-OF-USE ORDINANCE; BELEN INDUSTRIAL PARK WATER SYSTEM[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Ord. No. 2009-11, §§ 1-10, adopted 11-16-2009, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as § Ch. 8.22, §§ 8.22.010-8.22.100, was at the discretion of the editor. See also the Code Comparative Table and Disposition Table. 
Cross Reference: Title 13, Public Services. 

8.22.010 - Introduction. 
    In accordance with the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act and State drinking water regulations, the Belen Industrial Park Water System must minimize contamination in drinking water. It is the intent of the Belen Industrial Park Water System to accomplish this through the installation and operation of point-of-use treatment systems which the Belen City Council has decided is the most protective and cost-efficient way to meet drinking water standards. 
(Ord. No. 2009-11, § 1, 2009) 
8.22.020 - Purpose and intent. 
    The City of Belen is passing this chapter in order to comply with the Safe Drinking Water Act, State drinking water regulations, and to protect the health of the consumers of water supplied by the Belen Industrial Park Water System. 
    The specific purposes of this chapter are: 
1.  To require the installation of point-of-use treatment systems to improve the quality of drinking water. 
2.  To minimize arsenic in drinking water supplied by the Belen Industrial Park Water System. 
3.  To provide for an operation, maintenance, and monitoring program for point-of-use treatment systems that will be installed as part of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2009-11, § 2, 2009) 
8.22.030 - Applicability. 
    This chapter applies to all customers connected to the Belen Industrial Park Water System and all customers who connect to the Belen Industrial Park Water System in the future. 
(Ord. No. 2009-11, § 3, 2009) 
8.22.040 - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    "Building" means a combination of any materials, whether portable or fixed, having a roof to form a structure for the shelter of persons, animals, or property. 
    "Consumer" means any person, corporation, or other entity using or receiving water from the Belen Industrial Park Water System. 
    "Customer" means any purchaser or buyer of water from the Belen Industrial Park Water System. 
    "Dwelling unit" means a house or other structure in which a person or persons live. 
    "Nonresidential user" is defined as a user of water provided by Belen Industrial Park Water System for purposes other than personal consumption. Such purposes may include, but are not limited to, resale, as a component or ingredient in other products designed for resale or service to the public, or otherwise providing water directly or indirectly to a person for the purposes of consumption. 
    "Owner of the premises" includes the legal owners, their agents, or authorized representatives. 
    "Person" means a human being, partnerships, associations, corporations, legal representatives, or trustees. 
    "Potable water" means any water supply intended or used for human consumption or other domestic use. 
    "Premises" means any real property to which water is provided, including all improvements, buildings, dwelling units, mobile homes, and other structures located on it. 
    "Residential user" is defined as any person occupying a dwelling unit receiving water from the Belen Industrial Park Water System for the purpose of personal consumption. 
    "Service connection" is the point of delivery at which the Belen Industrial Park Water System connects to the private supply line. 
    "Structure" means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires a fixed location on the ground or attached to something located on the ground. 
    "Tap" means any faucet, spigot, or fountain that supplies water for consumption by drinking or cooking (including ice). 
    "Treatment unit" includes any device installed by the Belen Industrial Park Water System to treat water as well as any associated equipment or devices, including separate taps, storage tanks, and bypass valves. 
    "Water supplier" means Belen Industrial Park Water System, its employees, agents, and authorized representatives. 
(Ord. No. 2009-11, § 4, 2009) 
8.22.050 - Nonresidential users. 
A.  Installation. 
1.  The owner of the premises or nonresidential users will allow the water supplier to install point-of-use treatment systems and all ancillary equipment needed for the proper operation of the treatment units. 
2.  Treatment units will be installed to supply treated water to locations designated for drinking water as outlined in the access and maintenance agreements. 
3.  Treatment units will be installed by a properly trained and certified person. All units will be installed in accordance with state and local codes, if any, and in accordance with the manufacturer's specifications. 
4.  Reasonable effort shall be made by the water supplier to restore areas impacted by the installation of point-of-use treatment systems and all ancillary equipment to pre-existing conditions. 
5.  Title to the treatment units remains with the water supplier. While in effect, this chapter shall run with the land and shall be enforceable on all parties having or acquiring any right, title, or interest in any premises. 
B.  Maintenance. 
1.  The water supplier will maintain the treatment units. Maintenance may include, but is not limited to: any required repair to, or replacement of a treatment unit; any sampling of a treatment unit or the water a treatment unit is treating; or any action deemed necessary by the water supplier for the ongoing operation of a treatment unit. 
a.  All maintenance will be conducted by a properly trained and certified person. 
2.  Regular maintenance. The owner of the premises or nonresidential users will provide the water supplier access to the treatment units on a regular basis so that the water supplier can maintain the treatment units. 
a.  The water supplier will periodically notify the owner of the premises, his agent, his authorized representative, or the nonresidential users of the intention to provide maintenance to a treatment unit. Notification will be provided by phone call and written letter. 
b.  Regular maintenance will be provided during normal business hours or as arranged between the water supplier and the owner of the premises. Sampling will occur as mandated by the New Mexico Environment Department and will be coordinated with the users. 
c.  In the event that the owner of the premises or nonresidential users will not be able to provide access to a treatment unit on the date and time specified in the notification, the owner of the premises or the nonresidential users will schedule an alternative time with the water supplier. 
3.  Emergency repairs or replacement. The nonresidential users must provide access to the treatment units for emergency or unexpected repairs or replacements. Refusal to allow entry may result in termination of service in accordance with Section 8.22.080 of this chapter. 
4.  In the event that a leak or other defect is detected with the POU treatment system or its ancillary equipment, the nonresidential user will notify the water supplier at (505) 966-2730 or (505) 966-2731 within twenty-four (24) hours of noticing the leak or other defect and follow all directions given by the water supplier. The water supplier shall arrange to repair the leak or other defect. 
5.  The owner of the premises and the nonresidential user shall not adjust, modify, repair, replace, remove, disconnect, bypass, or otherwise tamper with a treatment unit. 
a.  The customer shall pay the water supplier for any costs incurred due to the adjusting, modifying, bypassing, tampering with, or removing a treatment unit or any ancillary equipment. 
6.  Users shall not perform any maintenance on the treatment units. 
(Ord. No. 2009-11, § 5, 2009) 
8.22.060 - Emergency suspension of utility service. 
A.  The water supplier may, without prior notice, suspend water service to any premises when such suspension is necessary to prevent or stop an actual or threatened imminent and substantial danger to the water supplier's public water supply. 
B.  The water supplier may, without prior notice, suspend water service to any premises when such suspension is necessary to prevent or stop an actual or threatened imminent and substantial danger to the environment or to the health or welfare of any person. 
C.  As soon as practicable after the emergency suspension of service, the water supplier will notify customers of the suspension. Notice will be provided in person or by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
D.  The water supplier will not reinstate service until the actual or threatened danger has been eliminated and its cause determined and corrected. 
1.  The customer shall pay the water supplier for any costs incurred for suspending service: responding to, eliminating, determining the cause of, and correcting actual or threatened dangers; and reinstating service, if the actual or threatened danger was caused by persons other than the water supplier. 
(Ord. No. 2009-11, § 6, 2009) 
8.22.070 - Nonemergency suspension of utility service. 
A.  The water supplier may terminate, after notice and opportunity for a hearing, the water service of any customer who: 
1.  Fails or refuses to allow the installation of treatment units as required by this chapter. 
2.  Fails or refuses to allow the water supplier access to the premises to conduct regular or emergency maintenance. 
3.  Adjusts, modifies, repairs, replaces, removes, disconnects, bypasses, or otherwise tampers with a treatment unit without prior written permission from the water supplier. 
B.  Except in accordance with Section 8.22.060 of this chapter, the water supplier will notify the customer of the proposed termination of water service at least thirty (30) days before the proposed termination. Notice will be provided in person or by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
1.  The customer may request a hearing on the proposed termination by filling in a written request for a hearing with the water supplier, not more than ten consecutive calendar days after receipt of notice of the proposed termination. 
C.  If water service is terminated, the water supplier will not reinstate water service until the customer and owner of the premises allow for the installation of treatment units. 
1.  The customer and the owner of the premises must enter into a written agreement to allow the water supplier access to the premises to conduct regular or emergency maintenance. 
D.  The customer shall pay all costs incurred by the water supplier to reinstate service. 
(Ord. No. 2009-11, § 7, 2009) 
8.22.080 - Liability. 
A.  The customer, owner of the premises, and nonresidential user shall indemnify and hold harmless the water supplier for any injury or damage which may occur as a result of: 
1.  The installation, maintenance, operation, sampling, monitoring, or removal of a treatment unit. 
2.  The adjusting, modifying, repairing, replacing, removing, disconnecting, bypassing, or otherwise tampering with a treatment unit. 
3.  The failure to inspect, detect, and report, in accordance with the chapter, any leaks or other defects which could have reasonably been detected by the required inspection. 
B.  The customer or the owner of the premises shall be liable for any damage to a treatment unit resulting from fire, theft, or impact. 
(Ord. No. 2009-11, § 8, 2009) 
8.22.090 - Severability. 
    If any provision or provisions of this chapter is held to be invalid, illegal, unenforceable, or in conflict with the law of any jurisdiction, the validity, legality, and enforceability of the remaining provisions shall not in any way be affected or impaired thereby. 
(Ord. No. 2009-11, § 9, 2009) 
8.22.100 - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall become effective five (5) days after publication of its adoption. 
(Ord. No. 2009-11, § 10, 2009) 
Title 9 - PUBLIC PEACE, MORALS AND WELFARE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 9.04 - CRIMINAL CODE 
Sections: 

9.04.010 - Adopted. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to ratify and adopt the 1980 Model Criminal Code Ordinance on General Offenses adopted by the city council of the city of Belen in public session on June 2, 1980 as set out in its entirety in Appendix 9.04 following this chapter. Amendments are noted where applicable. 
(Amended during 1998 codification; Ord. 1982-3 (part)) 
Appendix 9.04 - CRIMINAL CODE ORDINANCE ON GENERAL OFFENSES 
Chapters: 
Chapter One - ORDINANCE AUTHORITY AND PENALTIES 
Sections: 

1-1-1 - Title. 
    This appendix is called and may be cited as the "Criminal Code Ordinance on General Offenses" for the municipality of Belen, New Mexico. 
1-1-2 - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of the Criminal Code Ordinance, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless it shall be otherwise expressly provided in any section of this ordinance, or unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of this ordinance: 
A.  "Accused" means any person charged with the violation of any ordinance of the municipality that imposes a penalty. 
B.  "Another," "other" means any other human being or legal entity, whether incorporated or unincorporated, including the United States, the State of New Mexico or any subdivision thereof. 
C.  "Anything of value" means any conceivable thing of the slightest value, tangible or intangible, movable or immovable, corporeal or incorporeal, public or private. The term is not necessarily synonymous with the traditional legal term "property." 
D.  "Battery" means the unlawful, intentional touching or application of force to the person of another, when done in a rude, insolent or angry manner. 
E.  "Bet" means a bargain in which the parties agree that, dependent upon chance, even though accompanied by some skill, one stands to win or lose anything of value specified in the agreement. A bet does not include: 
1.  Bona fide business transactions which are valid under the laws of contracts, including, without limitation: 
a.  contracts for the purchase or sale, at a future date, of securities or other commodities; and 
b.  agreements to compensate for loss caused by the happening of chance, including, without limitation, contracts for indemnity or guarantee and life and health and accident insurance; 
2.  Offers of purses, prizes or premiums to the actual contestants in any bona fide contest for the determination of skill, speed, strength or endurance or to the bona fide owners of animals or vehicles entered in such contest; 
3.  A lottery which is defined as an enterprise wherein, for a consideration, the participants are given an opportunity to win a prize, the award of which is determined by chance, even though accompanied by some skill. As used in this subsection, "consideration" means anything of pecuniary value required to be paid to the promoter in order to participate in such enterprise; or 
4.  Betting otherwise permitted by law. 
F.  "Carrying a deadly weapon" means being armed with a deadly weapon by having it on the person, or in close proximity thereto, so that the weapon is readily accessible for use. 
G.  "Defendant" means any person accused of a violation of any ordinance of the municipality that imposes a penalty. 
H.  "Disorderly conduct" means engaging in violent, abusive, indecent, profane, boisterous, unreasonably loud or otherwise disorderly conduct which tends to disturb the peace, or maliciously disturbing, threatening or, in an insolent manner, intentionally touching any house occupied by any person. 
I.  "Governing body" means the city council or city commission of a city, the board of trustees of a town or village. 
J.  "He" or "him" or "she" or "hey" shall not be construed to be mandatory distinctions of gender if not expressly stipulated. 
K.  "Lawful custody or confinement" means the holding of any person pursuant to lawful authority, including, without limitation, actual or constructive custody of prisoners temporarily outside a penal institution, reformatory, jail, prison farm or ranch. 
L.  "Mayor" means the chief executive officer of municipalities having the mayor-council form of government. 
M.  "Minor" means any unmarried person who has not reached his or her eighteenth birthday, except that under application of the Alcohol Beverage Control Act, or any alcohol-related division of this ordinance, "minor" means any person under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
N.  "Municipality" means any incorporated city, town or village, whether incorporated under general act, special act or special charter. 
O.  "Official proceeding" means a proceeding heard before any legislative, judicial, administrative or other governmental agency or official authorized to hear evidence under oath, including any referee, hearing examiner, commissioner, notary or other person taking testimony or depositions in any proceeding. 
P.  "Person" means any human being or legal entity, whether incorporated or unincorporated. 
Q.  "Police officer," "law enforcement officer," "peace officer" or "officer" means any public official or public officer vested by law with a duty to maintain public order or to make arrests for crimes, whether that duty extends to all crimes or is limited to specific crimes. 
R.  "Prostitution" means knowingly engaging in or offering to engage in sexual intercourse for hire. 
S.  "Public employee" means any person receiving remuneration for regular services rendered to the state or any of its political subdivisions. 
T.  "Public ground" means any real property owned or leased by a municipality. 
U.  "Public officer" means any elected or appointed officer of the state or any of its political subdivisions, serving with or without remuneration for his or her services. 
V.  "Shall" is mandatory and "may" is permissive. 
W.  "Street" means any thoroughfare that can accommodate pedestrian or vehicular traffic, is open to the public and is under the control of the municipality. 
1-1-3 - Amendments. 
    Any amendments to this ordinance shall be adopted as ordinances as required by state law, and when passed in such form as to indicate the intention to make the same a part thereof, shall be incorporated into this ordinance so that reference to it as "the Criminal Code Ordinance on General Offenses," shall be understood as including such amendments. 
1-1-4 - Penalty. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be fined not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or imprisoned for a period of not more than ninety days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, and each day this ordinance is violated shall constitute a separate offense; provided, however, that if a specific penalty is provided therefor in any particular and individual section of this ordinance, then the specific penalty shall prevail. 
1-1-5 - Severability. 
    Should any section, paragraph, clause or provision of this ordinance, for any reason, be held to be invalid or unenforceable, the invalidity or unenforceability of such section, paragraph, clause or provision shall not affect any of the remaining provisions of this ordinance. 
1-1-6 - Repealer. 
    All ordinances or resolutions, or parts thereof, inconsistent herewith are repealed to the extent only of such inconsistency. This repealer shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or resolution, or part thereof, heretofore repealed. 
1-1-7 - Effective date. 
    This ordinance shall be in full force and effect five days after its adoption, approval and publication as provided by law. 
Chapter Two - PUBLIC ORDER AND SAFETY 
Sections: 

2-1-1 - Assault. 
    It is unlawful for any person to commit a battery upon the person of another, nor shall any person, by any unlawful act, threat or menacing conduct, cause another person to believe he or she is in danger of receiving an immediate battery, nor shall any person, by the use of insulting language toward another, impugn his or her honor, delicacy or reputation. 
2-1-2 - Battery. 
    It is unlawful for any person to beat, strike, wound, inflict violence or apply force to the person of another, nor shall a person intentionally touch or apply force to the person of another in a rude, insolent, angry or hostile manner except in connection with an exhibition duly authorized and licensed under law, or in lawful self defense, or in the line of duty as a duly authorized police officer as circumstances warrant. 
2-1-3 - Aggravated battery. 
    It is unlawful for any person to commit aggravated battery upon the person of another, nor shall any person unlawfully touch or apply force to the person of another with intent to injure that person or another, or inflict an injury to the person which is not likely to cause death or great bodily harm, but does cause painful temporary disfigurement or temporary loss or impairment of the functions of any member or organ of the body. 
2-1-4 - Trespass. 
    It is unlawful to enter or remain, with malicious intent, on the property of another knowing that consent to enter or remain has been denied or withdrawn by the owner or occupant thereof. 
2-1-5 - Prowling.
