The airport manager will be notified of each individual by the operator. No unauthorized independent operator will be allowed to conduct business transactions on the airport. 
2.  On-site Operator. 
a.  Operators on field shall negotiate a lease with adequate space to provide necessary and satisfactory building, attached buildings, parking lot and other facilities to furnish the specified aviation services selected. The lease space will be located in an area consistent with the airport master plan and subject to approval by the airport manager, the airport commission and the city. 
b.  The operator shall procure and maintain service documents, parts, lubricants, stands, tools, jacks, towing equipment, tire repair equipment, oxygen supplies, fire extinguishers, as required to meet FAA standards and have or be able to obtain disabled aircraft recovery equipment. 
3.  Hours of Operation. The operator shall have the premises open and services available during reasonable business hours. The operator shall make provision for someone to be in attendance in the office at all times during reasonable business operating hours. 
4.  Personnel. The operator shall have in his or her employ, and on duty during business hours, properly FAA certificated and trained personnel in such numbers as are required to meet the minimum standards set forth in an efficient manner. The operator shall also maintain, during all business hours, a responsible person in charge to supervise the operations in the leased area with the authorization to represent and act for and on behalf of the operator. 
(Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
11.08.070 - Aircraft lease and rental. 
A.  Statement of Concept. An aircraft lease or rental operator engaging in the rental or lease of aircraft to the public. 
B.  Minimum Standards. 
1.  Off-site Operator. Any prospective off-site operator shall work through an established operator on the field by means of a written independent contract labor agreement with the lessee or city. The airport manager will be notified of each individual by the operator. No unauthorized independent operator will be allowed to conduct business transactions on the airport. 
2.  On-site Operator. 
a.  Operators on field shall negotiate a lease with adequate space to provide necessary and satisfactory building, attached buildings, parking lot and other facilities to furnish the specified aviation services selected. The lease space will be located in an area consistent with the airport master plan and subject to approval by the airport manager, the airport commission and the city. 
b.  The operator shall have available for rental, either owned or under written lease to operator, at least one certified and currently airworthy aircraft maintained in accordance with the Federal Aviation Regulations (FARs). 
3.  Hours of Operations. The operator shall have the premises open and services available during reasonable business hours, with on-call services seven days a week. The operator shall make provision for someone to be in attendance in the office at all times during reasonable business hours. 
4.  Personnel. The operator shall have in his or her employ, and on duty during the appropriate business hours, trained personnel in such numbers as are required to meet the minimum standards set forth in an efficient manner including an FAA certificated flight instructor with appropriate ratings. The operator shall also maintain, during all business hours, a responsible person in charge to supervise the operations in the leased area with the authorization to represent and act for and on behalf of the operator. 
(Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
11.08.080 - Flight training. 
A.  Statement of Concept. A flight training operator engaging in instructing pilots in dual and solo flight training, in fixed or rotary wing aircraft, and provides such related ground school instruction as is necessary preparatory to taking a written examination and flight check ride for the category or categories of pilots' licenses and ratings involved. 
B.  Minimum Standards. 
1.  Off-site Operator. Any prospective off-site operators shall work through an established operator on the field by means of a written independent contract labor agreement with the lessee or city. The airport manager will be notified of each individual by the operator. No unauthorized independent operator will be allowed to conduct business transactions on the airport. 
2.  On-site Operator. 
a.  Operators on field shall negotiate a lease with adequate space to provide necessary and satisfactory building, attached buildings, parking lot and other facilities to furnish the specified aviation services selected. The lease space will be located in an area consistent with the airport master plan and subject to approval by the airport manager, the airport commission and the city. 
b.  The operator shall have available for use in flight training, either owned or under written lease to operator, at least one properly certificated aircraft maintained in accordance with FARs. 
3.  Hours of Operation. The operator shall have the premises open and services available during reasonable business hours. The operator shall make provision for someone to be in attendance in the office at all times during reasonable business hours. 
4.  Personnel. The operator shall have in his or her employ, and on duty during the appropriate business hours; trained personnel in such numbers as are required to meet the minimum standards set forth in an efficient manner. The operator shall also maintain, during all business hours, a responsible person in charge to supervise the operations in the leased area with the authorization to represent and act for and on behalf of the operator, and have a current FAA certified instructor pilot with appropriate ratings available all published hours of operation, unless briefing, debriefing or flying with a student. 
(Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
11.08.090 - Aircraft fuels and oil service. 
A.  Statement of Concept. Fuel and oil services include the sale and into-plane delivery of recognized brands of aviation fuels, lubricants, and other-related aviation petroleum products. The operator shall provide servicing of aircraft, including ramp assistance, parking, storage capability, and tie-down. No charge will be made for tie-down on the public ramp. An operator may provide self-service fueling but shall provide additional aviation services in conjunction. 
B.  Minimum Standards. 
1.  Off-site Operator. No unauthorized operator shall provide fuel on the airport. Any self-fueling by aircraft owners will be subject to the category on noncommercial aviation fuel usage, Uniform Fire Code and the current fuel flow fee regulations. 
2.  On-site Operator. 
a.  Operators on field shall negotiate a lease with adequate space to provide necessary and satisfactory building, attached buildings, parking lot and other facilities to furnish the specified aviation services selected. The lease space will be located in an area consistent with the airport master plan and subject to approval by the airport manager, the airport commission and the city. 
b.  The operator shall provide their own bulk fuel storage facility that is in compliance with all local, state, and federal regulations with regards to fuel storage. The storage shall be capable of maintaining at a minimum five thousand (5,000) gallon capacity for each grade of fuel maintained by the operator. The operator shall provide the required pumping equipment, either mobile or fixed, to meet all applicable safety requirements and shall provide reliable metering devices, personnel training, and quality control that conforms to current industrial standards and all federal, state, and local regulations. 
c.  The operator shall provide flight planning facilities, including for reference and for sale, current approved aviation maps and charts of the area within five hundred (500) nautical miles of the airport, a table suitable for flight planning by the pilot and at least a toll-free telephone connection to flight service. 
d.  The operator shall also provide some form of food and beverage service (vending machines with fresh food are acceptable). 
e.  The operator shall procure and maintain compressed air, towing equipment, 12/24 volt battery cart or equivalent, and fire extinguishers. All equipment shall be maintained and operated in accordance with local and state industrial and fire codes. 
f.  The operator shall notify the airport manager immediately of any changes in fueling capability. 
3.  Hours of Operation. The operator shall have the premises open and services available during reasonable business hours and provide on-call aircraft servicing during all other hours. The operator may close on Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Years, and Easter. The airport manager shall be notified of the days closed. The operator shall provide for call-out service within thirty (30) minutes for those days and after hours. The operator shall make provision for someone to be in attendance on the airport during reasonable business hours. If the operator provides a self-fueling facility, it shall be operational seven days a week, twenty-four (24) hours. 
4.  Personnel. The operator shall have in his or her employ, and on duty during the appropriate business hours, trained personnel in accordance with FAA regulation, fire code or as referred in this section of these standards, and in such numbers as are required to meet the minimum standards set forth in an efficient manner. The operator shall also maintain, during all business hours, a responsible person in charge to supervise the operations in the leased area with the authorization to represent and act for and on behalf of the operator. 
5.  Training of Personnel. The operator will have documented and approved training programs for fuel personnel. Annual proof of fuel training shall be kept on file and submitted upon request for all employees fueling aircraft. 
6.  Fuel Flow Records and Fees. The operator shall maintain an accurate record of all deliveries of aviation fuel. Such records shall be subject to examination and audit by the city or its representatives on request during business hours. The operator shall comply and pay the city the fuel flowage fee as determined by ordinance and/or the agreement between operator and the city. A copy of delivery documentation shall be submitted monthly with the report and payment. 
(Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
11.08.100 - Radio, instrument, or propeller repair station. 
A.  Statement of Concept. A radio, instrument, or propeller repair station operator engaging in the business of and providing a shop for the repair of aircraft radios, propellers, and instruments, for general aviation aircraft. This category shall include the sale of new or used aircraft radios, propellers, and instruments, but such is not an exclusive right. The operator shall hold the appropriate repair shop certificates issued by the FAA. 
B.  Minimum Standards. 
1.  Off-site Operator. Any prospective off-site operator shall work through an established operator on the field by means of a written independent contract labor agreement with the lessee or city. The airport manager will be notified of each individual by the operator. No unauthorized independent operator will be allowed to conduct business transactions on the airport. 
2.  On-site Operator. Operators on field shall negotiate a lease with adequate space to provide necessary and satisfactory building, attached buildings, parking lot, restroom and other facilities to furnish the specified aviation services selected. The lease space will be located in an area consistent with the airport master plan and subject to approval by the airport manager, the airport commission and the city. 
3.  Hours of Operation. The operator shall have the premises open and services available during reasonable business hours. 
4.  Personnel. The operator shall have in his or her employ, and on duty during the appropriate business hours, trained personnel in such numbers as are required to meet the minimum standards set forth in an efficient manner, but never less than one person who is an FAA-rated radio, instrument or propeller repairman as required by FAA repair station certificate. 
(Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
11.08.110 - Aircraft charter, air taxi, leased or independent fragmented ownership. 
A.  Statement of Concept. An aircraft charter, air taxi, leased or independent fragmented owner engaged in the business of providing air transportation (persons or property) to the general public or group for hire, either under a lease agreement, charter basis, air taxi, or demand as defined by the FAA regulations. The operator shall obtain and maintain the required FAA operating certificates. 
B.  Minimum Standards. 
1.  Off-site Operator. Any prospective off-site operator shall work through an established operator on the field by means of a written independent contract labor agreement with the lessee or city. The airport manager will be notified of each individual by the operator. Individuals providing independent leased or fragmented services will be required to obtain a concession agreement with the city. Rates and charges will be determined by the current fee structure. No unauthorized independent operator will be allowed to conduct business transactions on the airport. 
2.  On-site Operator. 
a.  Operators on field shall negotiate a lease with adequate space to provide necessary and satisfactory building, attached buildings, parking lot and other facilities to furnish the specified aviation services selected. The lease space will be located in an area consistent with the airport master plan and subject to approval by the airport manager, the airport commission and the city. 
b.  Operator shall have access to at least one airworthy aircraft per FAA regulations. 
c.  Operator shall meet the minimum FAA requirements as per Parts 119, 121, 135, or any other applicable FAR when operating for hire or lease. 
3.  Hours of Operation. Because of the "on-demand" type of business, the hours of operation will be up to the operator. However, they must be able to be contacted by telephone during the normal business hours of 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., five days a week. Operators shall provide on-call service during nonoperating hours, seven days per week with aircraft availability within a reasonable period of time. 
4.  Personnel. The operator shall have on duty during the appropriate business hours, at least one properly FAA-certified commercial pilot that will meet the requirements for the operating certificate held, or the type of commercial aircraft lease agreement. 
(Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
11.08.120 - Aircraft storage. 
A.  Statement of Concept. An aircraft storage operator engaging in the ownership and/or rental of conventional hangars or multiple T-hangars. 
B.  Minimum Standards. 
1.  On-site Operator. Operators on field shall negotiate a lease with adequate space to provide necessary and satisfactory building, attached buildings, parking lot, restroom, and other facilities to furnish the specified aviation services selected. The lease space will be located in an area consistent with the airport master plan and subject to approval by the airport manager, the airport commission and the city. 
2.  Hours of Operation. The operator providing conventional hangar storage shall have the premises available for the tenant's aircraft removal and storage twenty-four (24) hours per day, seven days a week, fifty-two (52) weeks per year. 
3.  Personnel. The operator shall have in his or her employ, and on duty during the appropriate business hours, trained personnel dependent upon the type of storage facility provided. 
(Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
11.08.130 - Specialized commercial flying services. 
A.  Statement of Concept. A specialized commercial flying service operator engaging in air transportation for hire for the purposes of providing the use of aircraft for the activities listed below: 
1.  Nonstop sightseeing flights that begin and end at the same airport; 
2.  Skydiving and parachuting; 
3.  Aerial sprayer, seeding, spraying, and bird chasing or counting; 
4.  Banner towing and aerial advertising; 
5.  Aerial photography or survey; 
6.  Power line or pipeline patrol; 
7.  Any other operations specifically excluded from Parts 119, 121, or 135 of the Federal Aviation Regulations. 
B.  Minimum Standards. 
1.  Off-site Operator. Any prospective off-site operator shall work through an established operator on the field by means of a written independent contract labor agreement with the lessee or city. The airport manager will be notified of each individual by the operator. No unauthorized independent operator will be allowed to conduct business transactions on the airport. 
2.  On-site Operator. Operators on field shall negotiate a lease with adequate space to provide necessary and satisfactory building, attached buildings, parking lot, restroom and other facilities to furnish the specified aviation services selected. The minimum areas in each instance shall be subject to the approval of the airport manager. The lease space will be located in an area consistent with the airport master plan and subject to approval by the airport manager, the airport commission and the city. 
b.  All aerial sprayers' operators shall make suitable arrangements and have such space available in the leased area for safe loading, unloading, storage, containment and disposal of chemical materials in accordance with the chemical label. The operator will comply with all federal and state regulations pertaining to a commercial spraying operation and the Federal Storm Water Protection Act. They will also provide a centrally drained, paved area large enough to contain washing and loading spillage and to facilitate its removal from the airport property. No dirt containment facilities will be allowed, unless the operator can provide an annual independent laboratory report that there has been no contamination. 
c.  All operators shall demonstrate that they have the availability of aircraft suitably equipped for the particular type of operation and shall have the required FAA certificate or waiver for the type of operation performed. 
3.  Personnel and Hours of Operation. The operator shall have in his or her employ, and on duty during appropriate business hours, trained personnel and FAA commercial-rated pilots in such numbers as may be required to meet the minimum standards set forth in this section in an efficient manner. 
(Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
11.08.140 - Multiple services. 
A.  Statement of Concept. A multiple services operator engaging in any two or more of the aeronautical services for which minimum standards have been before provided in this chapter. 
B.  Minimum Standards. 
1.  Off-site Operator. Any prospective off-site operator shall work through an established operator on the field by means of a written independent contract labor agreement with the lessee or city. The airport manager will be notified of each individual by the operator. No unauthorized independent operator will be allowed to conduct business transactions on the airport. 
2.  On-site Operator. 
a.  Operators on field shall negotiate a lease with adequate space to provide necessary and satisfactory building, attached buildings, parking lot, restroom and other facilities to furnish the specified aviation services selected. 
b.  The operator shall comply with the aircraft requirements, including the equipment thereon for each aeronautical service to be performed, except that multiple uses can be made of all aircraft with the exception of aircraft used for crop dusting, aerial application, or other commercial use of chemicals (unless specifically authorized by the FAA in regards to air worthiness). 
c.  The operator shall provide the facilities, equipment and services required to meet the minimum standards as hereinbefore provided for each aeronautical service the operator is performing. The lease space will be located in an area consistent with the airport master plan and subject to approval by the airport manager, the airport commission and the city. 
3.  Hours of Operation. The operator shall adhere to the hours of operation required for each aeronautical service being performed. 
4.  Personnel. The operator shall have in his or her employ, and on duty during the appropriate business hours, trained personnel in such numbers as are required to meet the minimum standards for each aeronautical service the operator is performing as hereinbefore provided. Multiple responsibilities may be assigned to meet the personnel requirements for each aeronautical service being performed by the operator. 
(Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
11.08.150 - Nonprofit aviation clubs. 
A.  Statement of Concept. The club must be a nonprofit corporation or partnership as defined in Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code. Each member must be a bona fide owner of the aircraft or owner of the corporation. The club shall be organized for the express purpose of providing its members with aviation materials, education, and/or aircraft for their personnel use and enjoyment only. Any commercial activity by the club is prohibited. The club will furnish copies of insurance policies, and a current list of members as reasonably necessary to ensure that the club is a nonprofit organization rather than an operator masquerading as a flying club. The club will comply with Appendix 8 of USDOT Order 5190.6A, except as for insurance limits which will be determined by the New Mexico Tort Claims Act. 
B.  Minimum Standards. 
1.  Off-site Operator. Any prospective off-site operator shall work through an established operator on the field by means of a written independent contract labor agreement with the lessee or city. The airport manager will be notified of each individual by the operator. No unauthorized independent operator will be allowed to conduct business transactions on the airport. 
2.  On-site Operator. 
a.  Operators on field shall negotiate a lease with adequate space to provide necessary and satisfactory building, attached buildings, parking lot, restroom and other facilities to furnish the specified aviation services selected. 
b.  The club may not derive greater revenue from the use of its aircraft than the amount necessary for the actual cost of operation, maintenance and replacement of its aircraft. The club will keep current a complete list of the club's membership and a record of club finances and will make such available to the city upon request. 
c.  In the event the club fails to comply with these conditions, the city will notify the club in writing of such violations. The club shall have fourteen (14) days to correct such violations. If the club fails to correct the violations, the city may remove the club from the airport. The lease space will be located in an area consistent with the airport master plan and subject to approval by the airport manager, the airport commission and the city. 
3.  Annual Requirements. 
a.  The club shall annually, on the date of its incorporation, provide to the city the following: 
i.  Proof of nonprofit status; 
ii.  Evidence of insurance; 
iii.  Proof of ownership, number, type and registration of aircraft, and evidence that all aircraft, equipment and facilities are properly certificated, licensed or owned by the club. 
4.  Maintenance. 
a.  Aircraft maintenance performed by the club shall be limited to club-owned aircraft only. 
(Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
11.08.160 - Self-fueling operations. 
A.  Statement of Concept. 
1.  Any tenant or aircraft owner operating aircraft on the airport may dispense aircraft fuel and oil into aircraft they own, lease for use, or manage, subject to the provisions of this section. 
2.  Any business, aircraft owner or pilot, not based on the airport, which comes onto the airport to conduct commercial operations involving the use of their aircraft and desiring to provide their own fuel shall be authorized to conduct self-fueling operations upon approval of the airport manager and the payment of a fee. 
3.  The self-fueler lessee may hangar, tie-down, adjust, repair, refuel, clean and otherwise service their own aircraft, provided they do so with their own employees in accordance with the established standards relating to such work. Lessee shall not dispense aircraft fuel to another airport user. Dispensing aircraft fuel is limited to lessee's own use in aircraft owned by it or leased for its exclusive use. 
B.  Minimum Standards for Tenants and Aircraft Owners. 
1.  Fueling Permit(s) Required. No tenant or aircraft owner shall engage in fueling operations at Belen Alexander Municipal Airport without having first been issued a fueling operations permit(s) by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport Manager. 
a.  Fueling Operations Permit-Application, Issuance and Renewal. 
i.  An applicant for the issuance or renewal of a fueling operations permit shall file with the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport Manager an application form provided for that purpose, which must be signed by the applicant. 
ii.  When an application has been filed with the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport Manager, the airport manager shall make an inspection of such applicant's site, equipment, and fuel dispensing and storage for the proposed fueling operations in order to ensure compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances or regulations. 
iii.  Belen Alexander Municipal Airport shall issue or renew a fueling operations permit within thirty (30) days of receipt of an application and the payment of the off-business self-fueling permit fee for each schedule day of operation unless one or more of the following is found to be true: 
(A)  The applicant has failed to provide required information or has provided false information in their application. 
(B)  The applicant's proposed fueling operations will violate an applicable law, ordinance, regulation or determined by the airport to interfere with the safety or aircraft operations at the airport. 
(C)  The applicant has had a fueling operation permit revoked or suspended within the two years preceding the date of the application. 
(D)  The applicant has failed to meet the minimum requirements of these regulations. 
b.  Display of Fueling Operations Permit. i. A permittee shall display a fueling operations permit issued by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport in a conspicuous place on the permittee's premises at all times. 
ii.  The permittee shall display a fueling operations permit issued by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport in the front windshield permanently affixed to the driver's side window on a movable card, but in plain view for inspection in the same location. 
c.  Cancellation by Permittee, Assignment and Transfer. 
i.  A permittee may cancel its fueling operations permit upon thirty (30) days written notice to the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport. 
ii.  A fueling operations permit is not assignable or transferable. 
d.  Revocation or Suspension of Permit. 
i.  The Belen Alexander Municipal Airport may revoke or suspend a fueling operations permit if it is determined that: 
(A)  The permittee has violated any provision of these regulations and has not made needed corrections in a timely manner as directed by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport; 
(B)  The permittee has given false or misleading information to the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport during the application process; 
(C)  The permittee has intentionally or knowingly impeded a lawful inspection by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport or other entity authorized to inspect the fueling operations of the permittee; 
(D)  The permittee has demonstrated an inability or willingness through repeated violations of these regulations and/or failure to take appropriate or adequate corrective actions, in the manner and time frame as directed by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport within a twelve (12) month period, committed one or more violations of these regulations and has failed to make needed corrections in a timely manner as directed by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport; or 
(E)  The permittee has failed to provide the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport with an up-to-date (monthly) self-fueling report of fuel dispensed and flowage fees paid, or maintained inspections of the self-fueling equipment and the retention of a log of the activity. 
C.  Minimum Standards for Off-Airport Business and Aircraft Owners. 
1.  Fueling Permit(s) Required. No off-airport business or aircraft owner shall engage in fueling operations at Belen Alexander Municipal Airport without having first been issued a temporary fueling operations permit(s) by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport Manager. 
a.  Fueling Operations Permit-Application, Issuance and Renewal. 
i.  An applicant for the issuance or renewal of a temporary fueling operations permit shall file with the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport Manager an application form provided for that purpose, which must be signed by the applicant. 
ii.  When an application has been filed with the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport Manager, the airport manager shall make an inspection of such applicant's site, equipment, and fuel dispensing and storage for the proposed fueling operations in order to ensure compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances or regulations. 
iii.  Belen Alexander Municipal Airport shall issue or renew a fueling operations permit within three days of receipt of an application unless one or more of the following is found to be true: 
(A)  The applicant has failed to provide required information or has provided false information in their application. 
(B)  The applicant's proposed fueling operations will violate an applicable law, ordinance, regulation or determined by the airport to interfere with the safety or aircraft operations at the airport. 
(C)  The applicant has had a fueling operation permit revoked or suspended within the two years preceding the date of the application. 
(D)  The applicant has failed to meet the minimum requirements of these regulations. 
b.  Display of Fueling Operations Permit. 
i.  A permittee shall display a temporary fueling operations permit issued by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport in a conspicuous place at the permittee's place of operations at all times. 
ii.  The permittee shall display a temporary fueling operations permit issued by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport in the front windshield permanently affixed to the driver's side window on a movable card, but in plain view for inspection in the same location. 
c.  Assignment and Transfer. A fueling operations permit is not assignable or transferable. 
d.  Revocation or Suspension of Permit. 
i.  The Belen Alexander Municipal Airport may revoke or suspend a fueling operations permit if it is determined that: 
(A)  The permittee has violated any provision of these regulations and has not made needed corrections in a timely manner as directed by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport; 
(B)  The permittee has given false or misleading information to the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport during the application process; 
(C)  The permittee has intentionally or knowingly impeded a lawful inspection by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport or other entity authorized to inspect the fueling operations of the permittee; or 
(D)  The permittee has demonstrated an inability or willingness through repeated violations of these regulations and/or failure to take appropriate or adequate corrective actions, in the manner and time frame as directed by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport within a twelve (12) month period, committed one or more violations of these regulations and has failed to make needed corrections in a timely manner as directed by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport. 
D.  Self-Fueling Permittee Responsibilities. 
1.  All into plane delivery of fuels shall be performed only at airport locations designated and published by the airport manager unless written permission is granted to the other locations by the airport manager. 
2.  A tenant or airport based aircraft owner permittee shall obtain the written approval of the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport prior to the construction or installation of any improvement on the permittee's leased premises. Temporary permittee shall not construct or install any improvements to the airport. 
3.  A permittee shall maintain all fueling facilities in a safe and clean condition equal in appearance and character to other similar airport improvements. 
4.  A permittee shall promptly repair any damage caused to the facilities or the airport by the permittee, the permittee's employees, agents, patrons, and guest. 
5.  A tenant or airport based aircraft owner permittee shall replace any fueling improvement on its leased premises which has been destroyed by fire, explosion, weather conditions, or disaster within sixty (60) days of such destruction. 
6.  Upon written notice, a tenant or airport based aircraft owner permittee shall perform any nonemergency reasonable facility maintenance that the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport determines is necessary. If a permittee fails to undertake such maintenance within three working days of receipt of the written notice, the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport may perform the maintenance and/or revoke or suspend the permit. If maintenance is performed by the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport, the permittee shall reimburse the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport for the cost of the maintenance performed. The Belen Alexander Municipal Airport reserves the right to order any fuel facility be placed out of service immediately if the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport determines in its best reasonable judgment that an unsafe condition exists. In such cases, tenant or aircraft owner is obligated to take appropriate corrective action immediately. 
7.  A tenant or airport based aircraft owner permittee shall require any prime contractor it hires for the construction of a permanent improvement to provide one hundred (100) percent performance bonds acceptable to the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport in the full amount of the construction contract for all contracts of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or more and fifty (50) percent payment bonds for contracts of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or more, naming the permittee and the city of Belen as joint obligees. 
8.  The permittee shall have in force general and environmental liability insurance. The permittee shall provide certificates of insurance indicating the coverages and in the amounts specified. Such insurance shall be placed with a company authorized to do business in the state of New Mexico. The city of Belen shall be named an additional insured. 
9.  All tenant or airport-based aircraft owner permittee shall present a fueling log to the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport no later than the fifth day of each month to reflect the previous calendar month. This shall include the amount of fuel dispensed and if none is dispensed it needs to be reported as such. 
E.  Self-Fueling Operations Minimum Standards. 
1.  Entities desiring to operate from privately owned hangars and/or to dispense aviation fuels and oil shall meet the following minimum operating standards. 
a.  A permittee shall, as required to meet local conditions as appropriate, develop, enforce, and maintain minimum standards for the storage, handling, and dispensing of fuels and lubricants on the airport as prescribed in: Reference No. IV: FAA Advisory Circular 150/5230-4 Changes 1 and 2, Aircraft Fuel Storage, Handling, and Dispensing on Airports., Appendix 7 Minimum Standards for Fuel Storage, Handling, and Dispensing on Airports., NFPA 30, Flammable and Combustible Liquids Code 2000 Edition., Air Transport Association Specification 103, Standards for Jet Fuel Quality at Airports, 1998 Revision-2000.1., NFPA 407-Standard for Aircraft Fuel Servicing (2001 Edition), NFPA Standard 415, Airport Terminal Buildings, Fueling Ramp Drainage, and Loading Walkways (1997 Edition), and American Petroleum Institute Standard 1542, Airport Equipment Marking for Fuel Identification (Fifth Edition), January 1991. 
b.  Self-fueling operations must be conducted in compliance with all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations. 
c.  Self-fueling operations may be conducted only by the aircraft owner, or his or her employees. 
d.  Self-fueling operations may be performed only at airport locations designated and published by the airport manager or on areas specifically designated for fueling. 
e.  No fuel may be dispensed into any aircraft other than those listed on the permit. 
f.  The current applicable fuel flowage fee shall be paid on all fuel dispensed under this category. 
g.  Permittee shall submit to the airport manager evidence of the training in safety procedures received by each person who will conduct fuel-dispensing operations on its premises. 
h.  Self-Fueling Facilities. 
i.  Only airport lessees shall be allowed to construct and maintain permanent self-fueling facilities. 
ii.  Lessee shall construct and maintain its facilities and shall conduct self-fueling operations in compliance with all applicable Belen Alexander Municipal Airport, state and federal laws and regulations, whether presently in effect or enacted hereafter. 
iii.  A self-fueling lessee shall provide at least one metered filter-equipped fixed dispenser for dispensing one hundred (100) octane or turbine fuels from above ground storage facilities having a minimum capacity of one thousand five hundred (1,500) gallons. Lessee shall maintain all fueling facilities in a safe and clean condition. 
i.  Self-Fueling Flowage Fee. A flowage fee of the amount established in the city of Belen ordinance on airport rates and fees will be paid to the Belen Alexander Municipal Airport by the self-fueler permittee for each gallon of fuel and oil delivered to permittee's storage facility. The city of Belen reserves the right to change the flowage fee at any time. 
(Ord. 2007-01 (part): Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
11.08.170 - Off-site operators subleasing or providing contract labor to another commercial operator on the airport. 
A.  Prior to finalizing an agreement or contract, the operator and the intended off-site operator shall obtain the written approval of the airport manager for the business proposed. The sublease or contract shall define the type of business and service to be offered by the off-site operator. 
B.  The off-site operator shall meet all of the minimum standards established by the city for the categories of services to be furnished by the operator. The minimum standards may be met by the operator or in combination with the off-site operator. The sublease or contract agreement shall specifically define those services to be provided by the operator to the off-site operator that shall be used to meet the standards. 
(Ord. 2005-18 (part)) 
Chapter 11.10 - AIRPORT RATES AND FEES 
Sections: 

11.10.010 - Land leases executed after the approval of this ordinance. 
A.  Revenue Producing Land Lease. The lease rate for tenants with land leases for the purpose of conducting business that produce revenue subject to New Mexico gross receipt taxes shall be a negotiated rate for each square foot of land leased plus a negotiated percent of all or a portion of gross receipts reported to the New Mexico taxation and revenue department, payable on a monthly basis. 
B.  Nonrevenue Producing Land Lease. The lease rate for tenants with land leases for the purpose of conducting business that do not produce revenue subject to New Mexico gross receipt taxes shall be a negotiated rate for each square foot of land leased, payable on a monthly basis. 
(Ord. 2006-03 (part)) 
11.10.020 - Subleasee gross receipt fee. 
    A monthly fee of three percent or three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00), whichever is less, shall be paid by every tenant and operator that subleases airport property from an airport leaseholder for the purpose of conducting business that produces revenue subject to New Mexico gross receipt taxes. Any subleasee claiming the three percent rate must present a copy of CRS-1 Form filed with the New Mexico Taxation and Revenue Department showing all gross receipts reported to the New Mexico Taxation and Revenue Department for the period for which the subleasee gross receipt fee is paid. 
(Ord. 2007-05: Ord. 2006-03 (part)) 
11.10.030 - Airport fuel flowage fee. 
    A fee of three cents shall be paid by all businesses and aircraft owners and operators, including ultralights, on each gallon of fuel and oil sold, dispensed or transferred via commercial fuel sales or self-fueling. This fee shall be paid on a monthly basis, however if the monthly amount due averages less than ten dollars then quarterly or semi-annual payments can be arranged with the Airport Manager. 
(Ord. 2006-03 (part)) 
11.10.040 - Airport monthly tie-down fee. 
    This fee shall be paid by all aircraft owners and operators parking their aircraft on the common use ramp for more than ten days per month. The fees are set as follows: single engine aircraft weighing less than twelve thousand five hundred (12,500) pounds: thirty dollars ($30.00) per month; single engine aircraft weighing over twelve thousand five hundred (12,500) pounds: forty-five dollars ($45.00) per month; multiple engine aircraft: fifty dollars ($50.00) per month. 
(Ord. 2006-03 (part)) 
11.10.050 - Commercial use ramp fee. 
    A fee of five dollars per day per aircraft or equivalent ramp space used for equipment or vehicles shall be paid by all businesses and aircraft owners and operators using the common use ramp space for commercial business operations. Such operations must be approved by the Airport Manager. 
(Ord. 2006-03 (part)) 
11.10.060 - Off-airport business use fee. 
    This fee is established as an incentive for businesses not to maintain offices and facilities off the airport yet use the airport to generate revenue on the airport for its business. This fee shall be paid by any business not based on the airport that comes onto airport property to provide aeronautical services. The fee shall not be paid by any business providing nonaeronautical maintenance or delivery services on the airport. The fees are set as follows: aeronautical business not competing with on-airport business: two hundred dollars ($200.00) annually. Aeronautical business competing with on-airport business: twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day or; one hundred dollars ($100.00) per calendar week when operating on the airport for four days or more or; one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) annually when operating for ten calendar weeks or more each calendar year. 
(Ord. 2006-03 (part)) 
11.10.070 - Off-airport business self-fueling permit fee. 
    This fee shall be paid by any business, aircraft owner or pilot, not based on the airport, which comes onto the airport to conduct commercial operations involving the use of their aircraft and desiring to provide their own fuel. This fee is set at one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day for each day of commercial operations. 
(Ord. 2006-03 (part)) 
11.10.080 - Past due accounts. 
A.  Late Fee. A late fee of one and one-half percent per month on the unpaid balance shall be paid on all past due payment due the city from the airport. 
B.  Ninety (90) or More Days Past Due. Any tenant or off-airport business user that is ninety (90) or more days past due on payments due the city shall have its airport lease placed into default or its authorization to conduct business on the airport suspended and given thirty (30) days to bring the payments current. 
(Ord. 2006-03 (part)) 
11.10.090 - Updating of airport rates and fees. 
    It is anticipated that the rates and fees established in this chapter shall be updated by amendment to the ordinance codified in this chapter as market forces dictate. 
    That this chapter shall be provided to every airport tenant, user and aircraft owner or operator. 
(Ord. 2006-03 (part)) 
Chapter 11.12 - AIRPORT ZONING REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

11.12.010 - Scope, authority and title. 
    These regulations are applicable to the area within a nine thousand (9,000) foot radius from the center of each end of the primary surface of each runway of each airport and connecting the adjacent arcs by lines tangent to those arcs at the Alexander Municipal Airport. These regulations divide said area into zones and within such zones, specify the land uses permitted, regulate and restrict the height to which structures and trees may be erected or allowed to grow, and impose other restrictions and requirements necessary to establish the approach plan for said airport, said airport zoning plan being herein formulated and adopted by the ordinance codified in this chapter, and the authority for same and for these regulations being NMSA 1978 Compilation, Sections 3-39-16 through 3-39-26, all as appearing in Laws of 1965, Chapter 300; and Federal Aviation Regulations, Part 77, Objects Affecting Navigable Airspace. 
    These regulations shall be known and may be cited as the Alexander Municipal Airport zoning regulations. 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 1) 
11.12.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in these regulations, unless the context otherwise requires: 
    "Airport" means Alexander Municipal Airport, near Belen, New Mexico. 
    "Airport elevation" means the established elevation of the highest point on the usable landing area, which is five thousand one hundred ninety-three (5,193) feet, MSL. 
    "Airport reference point" means the point established as the approximate geographic center of the airport landing area and is established at a location described as follows: Longitude 106°49'57?W, Latitude 34°38'51?N. 
    Height. For this purpose of determining the height limits in all zones set forth in these regulations and shown on the zoning map, the datum shall be mean sea level unless otherwise specified. 
    "Landing area" means the area of the airport used for the landing or take-off of aircraft. 
    "Nonconforming use" means any structure, tree or use of land which is lawfully in existence at the time these regulations become effective and does not then meet the requirements of said regulations. 
    "Primary surface" means a surface longitudinally centered on a runway and extending two hundred (200) feet beyond each end of that runway provided the surface is hard otherwise the primary surface ends at each end of that runway. The primary surface is established as two hundred (200) feet beyond each end of the runways and has a width of five hundred (500) feet. 
    "Runway" means the surface of an airport landing strip. 
    Other definitions are as set out in NMSA 1978 Compilation, 3-39-17; and in Federal Aviation Regulations, Part 77, Objects Affecting Navigable Airspace. 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 2) 
11.12.030 - Zones. 
    In order to carry out the provisions of these regulations, there are created and established certain zones which include all of the land lying within the approach zones, transition zones, horizontal zone and conical zone. Such areas and zones are shown on the Alexander Municipal Airport zoning map consisting of one sheet, adopted by the city council and dated May, 1979, a copy of which is attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter and made a part hereof. The various zones are hereby established and defined as follows: 
A.  Approach Zones. An approach zone is established at each end of all runways on the Alexander Municipal Airport for landings and take-offs. The approach zone shall be longitudinally centered on the extended runway centerline and extending outward and upward from each end of the primary surface and having a width of five hundred (500) feet at a distance of two hundred (200) feet beyond each end of the runway, widening thereafter uniformly to a width of two thousand (2,000) feet at a horizontal distance of five thousand (5,000) feet at a slope of twenty (20) feet horizontally to one foot vertically beyond each end of the runway. 
B.  Transition Zones. Transition zones are established adjacent to each runway and approach zone as indicated on the zoning map. Transition zones extend outward and upward at right angles to the runway centerline at a slope of seven feet horizontally to one foot vertically from the sides of the primary surface and from the sides of the approach sides of the primary surface and from the sides of the approach surfaces to the point where they intersect the surface of the horizontal zones, or the conical zone. 
C.  Horizontal Zones. A horizontal zone is established as within the perimeter of which is constructed by swinging arcs of a radius of five thousand (5,000) feet from the center of each end of the primary surface of each runway of each airport and connecting the adjacent arcs by lines tangent to those arcs. The horizontal zone does not include the approach zones, conical zones, and the transition zones. 
D.  Conical Zones. A conical zone is hereby established as the area that commences at the periphery of the horizontal zones and extends outward therefrom at a slope of twenty (20) feet horizontally to one foot vertically for a horizontal distance of four thousand (4,000) feet. The conical zone does not include the approach zones and transition zones. 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 3) 
11.12.040 - Height limitations. 
    Except as otherwise provided in these regulations, no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, allowed to grow, or maintained in any zone created by these regulations to a height in excess of the height limit herein established for each zone. Such height limitations are established for each of the zones in question as follows: 
A.  Approach Zones. One foot in height for each twenty (20) feet in horizontal distance beginning at a point two hundred (200) feet from and at the elevation of the end of the runway and extending to a point five thousand two hundred (5,200) feet from the end of the runway; 
B.  Transition Zones. One foot in height for each seven feet in horizontal distance beginning at any point two hundred fifty (250) feet normal to and at the elevation of the centerline of the runways extending two hundred (200) feet beyond each end thereof, extending to a height of one hundred fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation which is five thousand one hundred ninety-three (5193) feet above the mean sea level. In addition to the foregoing, there are established height limits of one foot vertical height for each seven feet horizontal distance measured from the edges of all approach zones for the entire length of the approach zones and extending upward and outward to the points where they intersect the horizontal, and conical surfaces; 
C.  Horizontal Zones. One hundred fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation or a height of five thousand three hundred forty-three (5343) feet above mean sea level; and 
D.  Conical Zone. One foot in height for each twenty (20) feet of horizontal distance beginning at the periphery of the horizontal zones, extending to a height of three hundred fifty (350) feet above the airport elevation. 
    Where an area is covered by more than one height limitation, the more restrictive limitations shall prevail. Nothing in these regulations shall be construed as prohibiting the growth, construction, or maintenance of any tree or structure to a height up to two hundred (200) feet above the surface of the land within a three mile radius of the airport reference point, except when such tree or structure intrudes within one of the restricted zones described above. 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 4) 
11.12.050 - Use restrictions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of these regulations, no use may be made of land within any zone established by these regulations in such manner as to create electrical interference with radio communication between the airport and aircraft, make it difficult for flyers to distinguish between airport lights and others, result in glare in the eyes of flyers using the airport, impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport or otherwise endanger the landing, taking-off, or maneuvering of aircraft. 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 5) 
11.12.060 - Nonconforming uses. 
A.  Regulations Not Retroactive. These regulations shall not be construed to require the removal, lowering, or other changes or alterations of any structure or tree not conforming to the regulations as of the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, nor otherwise interfere with the continuance of any nonconforming use. Nothing herein contained shall require any change in the construction, alteration or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of which was begun prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter and is diligently prosecuted. 
B.  Marking and Lighting. Notwithstanding the preceding provision of this section, the owner of any nonconforming structure or tree is required to permit the installation, operation, and maintenance thereon of such markers and lights as shall be deemed necessary by the city council to indicate to the operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport, the presence of such airport hazards. Such markers and lights shall be installed, operated, and maintained at the expense of the owner of the nonconforming tree or structure, and shall conform to the current Federal Aviation Administration, Advisory Circular 70/7460-1. 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 6) 
11.12.070 - Permits. 
A.  Future Uses. Except as specifically provided in subsections (A)(1), (2) and (3) of this section, no material change shall be made in the use of the land and no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, planted or otherwise established in any zone created unless a permit therefor shall have been applied for and granted. Each application for a permit shall indicate the purpose for which the permit is desired, with sufficient particularity to permit it to be determined whether the resulting use, structure or tree would conform to the regulations herein prescribed. If such determination is in the affirmative, the permit shall be granted. 
1.  In the area lying within the limits of the horizontal zone and conical zone but not within the limits of an approach zone or transition zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than one hundred fifty (150) feet of vertical height above the ground except when because of terrain, land contour or topographic features such tree or structure would extend above the height limits prescribed for such zone. 
2.  In the areas lying within the limits of the approach zones but at a horizontal distance of not less than one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet from each end of the runways, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than fifty (50) feet of vertical height above the established airport elevation, except when such tree or structure would extend above the height limit prescribed for such instrument or noninstrument approach zone. 
3.  In the areas lying within the limits of the conical zones beyond the perimeter of the horizontal zones, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than one hundred fifty (150) feet of vertical height above the ground except when such tree or structure, because of terrain, land contour or topographic feature would extend above the height limit prescribed for such conical zones. 
    Nothing contained in any of the foregoing exceptions shall be construed as permitting or intending to permit any construction, alteration or growth of any structure or tree in excess of any of the height limits established by these regulations except as set forth in Section 11.12.040. 
B.  Existing Uses. No permit shall be granted that would allow the establishment or creation of an airport hazard or permit a non-conforming use, structure, or tree to be made or become higher, or become a greater hazard to air navigation, than it was on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter or any amendments thereto or than it is when the application for a permit is made. Except as indicated, all applications for such a permit shall be granted. 
C.  Nonconforming Uses Abandoned or Destroyed. Whenever the city council determines that a nonconforming structure or tree has been abandoned or more than eighty (80) percent torn down, physically deteriorated, or decayed, no permit shall be granted that would allow such structure or tree to exceed the applicable height limit or otherwise deviate from the zoning regulations. 
D.  Variances. Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any structure, or permit the growth of any tree, or use his or her property, not in accordance with these regulations, may apply to the city council for a variance from such regulations. Such variances shall be allowed where it is duly found that a literal application or enforcement of the regulations would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship and the relief granted would not be contrary to the public interest but will do substantial justice and be in accordance with the spirit of these regulations. 
E.  Hazard Marking and Lighting. Any permit or variance granted may, if such action is deemed advisable to carry out the purpose of these regulations and be reasonable in the circumstances, be so conditioned as to require the owner of the structure or trees in question to, at his or her own expense, install, operate, and maintain thereon such markers and lights as may be necessary to indicate to flyers the presence of an airport hazard. 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 7) 
11.12.080 - Administration. 
    It shall be the duty of the city council to administer and enforce the regulations prescribed herein. Applications for permits and variances shall be made to said council upon forms furnished by it. Applications required by these regulations to be submitted to said council shall be promptly considered and granted or denied by it. 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 8) 
11.12.090 - Board of appeals and appeals. 
    There is created a board of appeals, and appeal rights and procedures, under and pursuant to NMSA 1978 Compilation, 3-39-22, sub-sections C, D (there being no existing board of appeals or adjustment), E, F, G, H, I, J (all as set out in Chapter 300, Laws of 1965). 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 9) 
11.12.100 - Judicial review. 
    Judicial review may be had as provided in, and under and pursuant to NMSA 1978 Compilation, 3-39-23, subsections A, B, C, D, E (all as set out in Chapter 300, Laws of 1965). 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 10) 
11.12.110 - Enforcement and remedies. 
    Violations, penalties, and additional relief are as provided in, and under and pursuant to NMSA 1978 Compilation, 3-39-24 (all as set out in Chapter 300, Laws of 1965). 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 11) 
11.12.120 - Conflicting regulations. 
    Where there exists a conflict between any of the regulations or limitations prescribed herein and any other regulations applicable to the same area, whether the conflict be with respect to the height of structures or trees, the use of land, or any other matter, the more stringent limitation or requirement shall govern and prevail. 
(Ord. 1981-5 § 12) 
Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 12.04 - EXCAVATIONS 
Sections: 

12.04.010 - Permit required. 
    No individual, party, or entity shall remove existing pavement or replace or dig into pavement or sidewalks or into any area owned or utilized by the city of Belen, whether as an easement or right-of-way or for public thoroughfare purposes for any purpose whatsoever without first obtaining a permit and paying therefor from the city manager, in his or her own proper person, or his or her formally designated representative. 
(Ord. 376 § 1, 1977) 
12.04.020 - City manager notification required. 
    Before any person, party, or entity shall endeavor to remove, replace, or dig into existing pavement, macadam, or sidewalks or into any city owned or utilized property and at the time of obtaining a permit, as above, said party shall notify the city manager individually or his or her designated agent five days before construction therefor shall be initiated. 
(Ord. 376 § 2, 1977) 
12.04.030 - Fee. 
    The fee for a paving cut, paving removal, or excavation, as above, shall be in the minimum sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) or three dollars a square foot, whichever is greater. 
(Ord. 376 § 3, 1977) 
12.04.040 - Procedures. 
    The following specifications shall govern the removal or replacement or excavation or activity as defined desiring in Section 12.04.020, supra, to-wit: 
A.  General. This work shall consist of removing and replacing existing flexible pavement failures over utility lines at the locations shown. The pavement replacement shall be in conformity with the materials, grade, dimensions, typical section, all as shown and specified herein. 
B.  Pavement Removal and Subgrade Preparation. The existing pavement shall be removed to a depth eight inches below the surface of the existing pavement. The vertical edges of the pavement cuts shall be perpendicular to the finished pavement surface. The existing subgrade shall be compacted with a vibratory pan type compactor, and when the moisture content of the subgrade is near optimum, immediately prior to the spreading of the cement treated base mixture, the surface of the prepared subgrade shall be moistened and kept moist, but not excessively wet until covered by spreading of the mixed material. 
C.  Pavement Patching Materials and Construction Methods. The base course material shall consist of a granular nonplastic material passing a one-inch screen mixed with water and Portland cement. The cement content shall be between two and four percent by weight. 
    The surface course shall consist of hot mix asphalt concrete conforming to all of the provisions of the New Mexico State Highway Commission Interim Specifications, April 1976 Edition, and all approved modifications thereto for Type II asphalt concrete. The asphalt concrete aggregate graduation shall be as follows: 
Sieve Size Percent Passing 3/4? 100 1/2? 70-100 3/8 ? 55-85 No. 4 40-65 No. 10 30-50 No. 40 15-30 No. 80 8-20 No. 200 4-9  
    The bituminous material for the hot mix shall be eighty-five (85) to one hundred (100) penetration asphalt cement and the hot mix shall contain approximately five and one-half percent asphalt by weight. 
    The previously mixed cement treated base material shall be placed on the prepared subgrate and compacted with a vibratory pan-type compactor. The surface of the compacted base shall be two inches below the surface of the existing pavement. The surface of the base course shall receive a bituminous prime coat of MC-1 applied at the rate of .30 gallons/per square yard and allowed to cure for forty-eight (48) hours. The hot mix surface course shall be applied and then compacted with an approved steel wheeled flat roller. After being compacted, the asphalt concrete shall conform with the adjacent existing pavement grade to provide a smooth riding surface. 
(Ord. 376 § 4, 1977) 
12.04.050 - Violation-Penalty. 
    It is unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person, party, or entity to remove, replace, dig or excavate pavement or into pavement, macadam, sidewalk, or in any area owned by the city or utilized by the city for public thoroughfare purposes without complying with the above designated requirements and specifications; a violation of this chapter shall constitute violation of a misdemeanor and said party, person, or entity upon conviction hereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or imprisonment in the city jail or any other confinement area designated by the municipal judge for not more than thirty (30) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 376 § 5, 1977) 
Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 13.04 - SEWER SERVICE SYSTEM[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-13, §§ 1, 2(Att.), adopted Oct. 16, 2017, repealed Ch. 13.04 in its entirety and enacted a new Ch. 13.04 to read as set out herein. Former Ch. 13.04 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1982-5, §§ 1-13. 

13.04.010 - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the sewer use ordinance of Belen, New Mexico. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13, § 2(Att.), 10-16-2017) 
13.04.020 - Definitions. 
    "A.S.T.M." means ASTM International. 
    "B.O.D." (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter by standard methods procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees centigrade expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
    "Building drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    "Building sewer" means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    "City" means the city of Belen, New Mexico. 
    "C.O.D." (denoting chemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the chemical oxidation of organic and inorganic matter under standard laboratory procedure by the dichromate reflux method expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    "Combined sewer" means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    "Decommission" means to withdraw from service, make inoperative, and dismantle and decontaminate it to make it safe. 
    "Garbage" means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food and from the handling, storage, and sale of produce. 
    "Grinder pump unit" means a wastewater conveyance device, which is utilized to pump a property's wastewater into the nearest gravitational sewer line. 
    "Industrial liquid wastes" means all waterborne solids, liquids or gaseous wastes resulting from any industrial manufacturing or food processing operation or process, or from the development of any natural resource or any mixture of these with water or domestic sewage as distinct from normal domestic sewage. 
    "Interference with any wastewater facility" means any condition or combination of conditions which cause degradation of the operational efficiency of a wastewater facility. 
    "Natural outlet" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater. 
    "Normal domestic wastewater" means waterborne wastes normally discharging from the sanitary conveniences of buildings, including apartment houses and hotels, office buildings, factories and institutions, free from storm surface water and industrial wastes. Normal domestic wastewater means "normal" for the city of Belen, New Mexico. 
    "pH" means the logarithm, to the base ten (10), of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half (1/2) inch in any dimension. 
    "Public sewer" means a sewer system, owned and operated by the municipality. 
    "Sanitary sewer" means the public sewer portion of a wastewater facility which transports wastewater and to which storm, surface and groundwater are not intentionally admitted. 
    "Settleable solids" means those solids which settle during a preselected period of time expressed as milliliters per liter of sample. 
    "Sewer Line" means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    "Sludge" means any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four (24) hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    "Standard methods" means the laboratory procedures set forth in the latest edition, at the time of analysis, of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" as prepared, approved and published jointly by the American Public Health Association and the American Water Works Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
    "Storm sewer" means a sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes wastewater and polluted industrial wastes. 
    "Suspended solids" means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    "Trap" means a device for retaining sand, silt, grit, mineral material, petroleum solvent, grease or oil by gravity-differential separation from wastewater and of a design and capacity approved by the city. 
    "Unpolluted process water" means any water or waste containing none of the following: free of emulsified grease or oil; acid or alkali, phenols or other substances imparting taste and odor to receiving water; toxic substances in suspension, colloidal state or solution; and noxious or odorous gases. 
    "Wastewater" means the used water of a community. Such used water may be a combination of the liquid and waterborne wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions. 
    "Wastewater facilities" means the structures, equipment and processes required to collect, transport and treat wastewater liquid and dispose of the effluent. 
    "Wastewater treatment facilities" means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with waste treatment plant or wastewater treatment plant. 
    "Watercourse" means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
    "W.P.C.F." means the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13, § 2(Att.), 10-16-2017) 
13.04.030 - Unpolluted discharges to sewers prohibited. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13, § 2(Att.), 10-16-2017) 
13.04.040 - Drainage discharge. 
    Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the public works. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the public works, to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13, § 2(Att.), 10-16-2017) 
13.04.050 - Untreated discharges prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any sewage or wastewater or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13, § 2(Att.), 10-16-2017) 
13.04.060 - Unauthorized disposal. 
    Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage within city limits when a city sewer connection is present. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13, § 2(Att.), 10-16-2017) 
13.04.070 - Sewer connection inside city limits. 
    All residential, commercial, institutional, and industrial property owners situated within the city limits are required to connect into city sewer lines, if available. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13, § 2(Att.), 10-16-2017) 
13.04.080 - Sewer connection outside city limits. 
    All residential, commercial, institutional and industrial properties situated outside the city limits may be connected into city sewer lines, if available. City connection may take place upon application, agreement and approval by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13, § 2(Att.), 10-16-2017) 
13.04.090 - Private sewage disposal. 
A.  When Permitted. Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of this chapter, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  Permit. Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the public works. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications, and other information as are deemed necessary by the public works. A permit and inspection fee shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
C.  Inspection. A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the public works. The public works shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the public works when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within seventy-two (72) hours of the receipt of notice by the public works. 
D.  Design Requirements. The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all requirements and recommendations of the New Mexico Environment Department. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than fifteen thousand (15,000) square feet. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
E.  Conversion to Public Sewer on Availability. At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article at which time any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned in accordance with New Mexico Environment Department standards. 
F.  Operation-Maintenance. The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times at no expense to the city. 
G.  Chapter Not to Limit Reasonable Requirements of the New Mexico Environment Department. No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed to interfere with any additional reasonable requirements that may be imposed by the New Mexico Environment Department. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13, § 2(Att.), 10-16-2017) 
13.04.100 - Building sewers. 
A.  Assessments, Responsibility of Maintenance, and Easements. Prior to submitting an application, the Applicant shall complete an assessment with city personnel to verify gravity or pressure connection, identify utilities and obstacles on the property, and develop easement documentation as required. For gravity systems, the property owner's responsibility ends at the boundary of the city right-of-way line. The city shall be responsible for construction of the service line from the private property boundary to the connection at the public sewer. For grinder pump systems, the city and the property owner shall develop a sketch of the property to be served and the desired location of the grinder pumping unit, pressure service line, control panel, water meter, water service line from meter to building, wells, any buried customer buried pipe lines, gas meter, electric meter, telephone, service box, cable TV service connection, estimated location of any buried utilities, gravity service line location and depth, and a north arrow. The property owner/customer shall grant an easement to the city for the installation and maintenance of the grinder pump system. Access onto the property shall be granted to install, inspect, and maintain, as deemed necessary by the city. 
B.  Permits Required. No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenances thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city public works department. 
C.  Permit Classes, Applications, Fees. There shall be four (4) classes of building sewer permits: 
1.  For residential; 
2.  Commercial; 
3.  Institutional establishments using up to or more than thirty-thousand (30,000) gallons of water per month; and 
4.  For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
    An application shall consist of: name, service address, mailing address, telephone number, the nature of the residential unit or commercial facility to be served, plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgement of the city public works department, required fees, an assessment, and easement documentation. 
D.  Costs Connection and Installation. Connection fees are due with the submission of an application. Fees for connecting to the system shall be as determined in the current adopted rate. The current adopted rate shall be established and may be amended periodically by resolution of the governing body. Fees for septic system removal will be covered by the property owner when the sewer line is being operated by a gravity system. Grinder pump fees are as follows: 
1.  For a grinder pump system inside city limits, the city shall be responsible for costs of septic system decommission, connection to existing building sewer, grinder pump unit, pressure service line, and electrical panel and installation using a city-approved contractors. The city shall provide the grinder pump to the contractor for installation, and maintain ownership of such grinder pump. 
2.  For a grinder pump system outside city limits, the property owner shall be responsible for costs of septic system decommission, connection to existing building sewer, pressure service line, and electrical panel and installation using the city's contractors. The city shall provide the grinder pump to the contractors for installation, and maintain ownership of such grinder pump. A deposit equivalent to fifty (50) percent of the system cost shall be submitted before the city's contractors may begin their work. 
E.  Separate Building Sewers Required. A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one (1) building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one (1) building sewer. 
F.  Use of Old Building Sewers. Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the public works, to meet all requirements of this chapter. 
G.  Design Requirements-Compliance with Codes.
